description: About half an hour into Cory Doctorows discussion of his new science-fiction novel, Walkaway, at the New York Public Library on Wednesday, the man interviewing him suddenly froze in midsentence.

title: U.K. Conservatives Gain and Labour Stumbles in Harbinger of General Election
description: LONDON  In voting for local councils on Thursday, just five weeks before the British general election, the governing Conservative Party made significant gains, the opposition Labour Party did badly and the centrist Liberal Democrats had mixed success.

title: The Art Market Is Still Waiting for an Online Revolution
description: LONDON  E-commerce is revolutionizing the world of retail. Online sales in the United States have grown by an average of $40 billion a year over the past three years, posing an existential threat to brick-and-mortar shopping. This year, Amazon is set to overtake Macys, which plans to close 100 stores, as Americas biggest apparel seller.

title: Bresha Meadows, an Ohio Teenager Accused of Killing Father, Seeks Release Before Trial
description: Bresha Meadows was 14 when she took her fathers gun and shot him last July, putting an end to what some relatives say were years of abuse visited upon her, her mother and her siblings.

title: Wizards vs. Celtics: Pushing, Shoving, and Occasional Basketball
description: WASHINGTON  Even as they clutter their games with pushes and shoves, with scuffles and kerfuffles, the Washington Wizards and the Boston Celtics share common ground.

title: 2017 Kentucky Derby Contenders: The Experts Make Their Picks
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The horses for the 143rd running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of post position, with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs.

title: E.U. Leader Says (in English) That English Is Waning
description: BRUSSELS  Jean-Claude Juncker couldnt resist a little dig, and it drew a big laugh.

title: A Season of Regret for an Aging Tribal Expert in India
description: NEW DELHI  At 82, the anthropologist T. N. Pandit passes his days in the gentle occupations of old age: poetry, a Buddhist study circle, a daily walk in the park. It is rare for anyone to ask him about the years he spent with the hunter-gatherer tribes of the Andaman Islands. Only with difficulty can he locate a single copy of the slender book he wrote about that time.

title: Were Getting Awfully Close to Full Employment
description: There is one prism through which we should analyze the April jobs numbers released Friday and each of the remaining reports in 2017: How close to full employment are we, really?

title: Regulator in China Takes Aim at Anbang Insurance Group
description: SHANGHAI  A Chinese regulator announced on Friday that it had taken disciplinary measures against the Anbang Insurance Group, a financial behemoth that has tried to invest tens of billions of dollars overseas, for the improper sale of two investment products.

title: Women Who Have the Chops (and the Punches and the Kicks)
description: Speeding car chases, heart-stopping hand-to-hand combat, bodies left for dead on the pavement, a backdrop of international espionage. The director David Leitchs latest film has all the elements of a Jason Bourne or James Bond blockbuster  except for one major difference. Its a woman throwing the punches.

title: Chris Kraus and Jill Soloway Talk About the Show I Love Dick
description: Twenty years ago, I Love Dick  Chris Krauss novel chronicling her one-sided obsession with a cultural critic named Dick and how she staked out her own identity as a writer through a wild series of letters to him  was published to little notice. Since then, it has grown into a feminist cult classic. The book anticipated an era of popular female autofiction  from Emily Goulds And the Heart Says Whatever to Sheila Hetis How Should a Person Be?  and with a cheeky title that feels made to be Instagrammed, it has taken on new resonance as a text for women in the social media age. This month, it will continue its pop cultural rise with a television adaptation by another feminist auteur.

title: A Taiwanese Classic Now Available in English
description: NOTES OF A CROCODILE By Qiu Miaojin Translated by Bonnie Huie 304 pp. New York Review Books. $15.95.

title: On the French Election
description: On Sunday France will hold its presidential runoff.

title: Jay Cutler Joins Fox as an N.F.L. Analyst
description: Jay Cutler, cut by the Chicago Bears after eight years as their starting quarterback, will leave the game to become an analyst on Fox.

title: The Hunted
description: In parts of southern Africa, people with albinism are killed or sold by traffickers.

title: Russia Says Deal Bars American Jets From Much of Syrias Skies. U.S. Says No.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  United States and allied aircraft will be banned from flying over much of Syria as part of a deal struck by Iran, Russia and Turkey to foster a cease-fire in the Syrian war, a senior Russian diplomat said Friday.

title: A Story Collection Tracks Nepals Highs and Somewhat Lows
description: MAD COUNTRY Stories By Samrat Upadhyay 294 pp. Soho Press. Paper, $16.

title: An Auschwitz Magicians Greatest Trick: Holding the Horrors at Bay
description: All right, pick a card, Werner Reich said, fanning out a worn deck of cards in his Long Island home to demonstrate a trick hed learned in an unlikely place: on the top of a bare wooden bunk in the concentration camp barracks at Auschwitz.

title: On the Mountain Top With a French Presidential Candidate
description: PAU, FRANCE  Not surprisingly its very different to travel with a French presidential candidate than with an American one. Granted, this was not an ordinary trip for Emmanuel Macron, the centrist candidate for president of France, but still. We (myself and the French photographer, Pierre Terdjman) took a flight at dawn down to Pau, which is inland from Biarritz and in the plains just below where the Pyrenees begin. There we joined with a press pool following Mr. Macron.

title: Classic Mediterranean Flavors, Enlivened by Ramps
description: In the Mediterranean pantry, olive oil reigns. Black and green olives in varying hues and sizes abound. Capers, the pickled flower buds of a wild vine, are a constant, too, at the ready with their briny, floral scent. Most cooks in the region use anchovies, preserved in salt or oil, in their daily cooking, in whole fillets, chopped or pounded in a mortar. Wild thyme, rosemary and oregano are the herbs of choice, and garlic is a given.

title: For Some, Britain Proved a Port in the Storm of War
description: LAST HOPE ISLAND Britain, Occupied Europe, and the Brotherhood That Helped Turn the Tide of War By Lynne Olson Illustrated. 553 pp. Random House. $30.

title: How Dr. Eric Kandel, Neuroscientist, Spends His Sundays
description: Forget that hes 87.  Eric R. Kandel, who specializes in the biology of memory and is a professor in the neuroscience and psychiatry departments at Columbia University, works more than he ever has before, he said. Dr. Kandel, who won a Nobel Prize in 2000, continues to write books and is co-director of the Mortimer B. Zuckerman Mind Brain Behavior Institute at Columbia and a senior investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Chevy Chase, Md. He lives with his wife of 60 years,  Denise Kandel, 84, an epidemiology professor at Columbia, in Harlem.

title: Sharing an Apartment With Strangers
description: Over the last decade, Long Island City, Queens, has become a refuge for Manhattan professionals who want a short commute and an apartment in an amenity-laden high-rise, but dont want to split a Murray Hill two-bedroom three ways to get it.

title: Rikers Deemed Too Dangerous for Transferred Inmates
description: The jail complex on Rikers Island has failed to comply with minimum safety standards and has become so dangerous, according to a New York State oversight agency, that it can no longer be permitted to accept inmate transfers from outside New York City.

title: A Kaleidoscopic John Giorno Retrospective, Sprinkled Around New York
description: Since the 1960s, John Giorno has been a nexus of New Yorks downtown art scene. This 80-year-old poet, artist and activist had been a muse of Andy Warhols and has hosted dinner parties with friends like Patti Smith, Robert Mapplethorpe and Keith Haring. In more recent years, he has collaborated with the French artist Pierre Huyghe and starred in the music video for R.E.M.s final single.

title: Theres No Escape From Contamination Above the Toxic Sea
description: BORNE By Jeff VanderMeer 323 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $26.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: House Republicans Move to Gut Bank Regulations
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans took a big step toward repealing the Affordable Care Act on Thursday, and they took a small step toward dismantling another of President Barack Obamas signature pieces of legislation, the Dodd-Frank Act.

title: Custom Stalls and Air-Ride Suspension: How Derby Horses Travel in Style
description: Like Nyquist, American Pharoah and California Chrome, the horse that wins Saturdays Kentucky Derby will be covered in a blanket of roses. And  whether or not it appreciates it  that horse will bask in the adulation of the finely turned-out spectators at Churchill Downs.

title: Poor Credit History Can Affect Homeowners Insurance Rates
description: The impact of ones credit history on homeowner insurance rates appears to be intensifying, a new analysis shows.

title: The Five Lies Hollywood Tells Itself
description: Were heading into blockbuster season, long designed to part young men with their money using male heroics, computerized wizardry and the requisite side babes. But in a sign that slow-to-react movie studios are betting theres lucre in catering to a wider array of audiences  something television has known for a while  the summer of 2017 is bringing alternates to tried and tired formulas, with the likes of Wonder Woman, starring Gal Gadot; Atomic Blonde, with Charlize Theron; and the Tupac Shakur biopic, All Eyez on Me, with Demetrius Shipp Jr. in the lead.

title: The Latest in Crime Fiction
description: Its hard to get good help these days. Thats the complaint of the stressed-out Glaswegian gangsters in EVERY NIGHT I DREAM OF HELL (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $26), a piece of writing that lives up to its gritty title. Its especially difficult to find disciplined professionals like Nate Colgan, an enforcer for the Jamieson gang and the reliable chronicler of Malcolm Mackays novel. Although hes skilled at handling the dirty jobs, Nate is no meathead. Times had changed, he explains. Big organizations had become more sophisticated and the standard of muscle had gone up.

title: Chicagos South Side Golf Courses in Line for a Tiger Woods Upgrade
description: CHICAGO  Gus Sims, 67, has heard what might happen to his beloved, no-frills public golf course on Chicagos South Side, where, on a balmy spring morning here, he was setting out to play a leisurely nine holes.

title: In a Law Office, Coping With a Bosss Toxic Trail
description: My first full-time job was in an estate planning law firm in Midtown Manhattan, working as a paralegal. It was 1992, I was 22 and, having just graduated from college with a double major in English and philosophy, I was ill qualified for just about everything in the nonacademic world. Nothing in my undergrad curriculum helped me write wills or powers of attorneys, or most important, as it turned out, make coffee for Mr. S.

title: Roasted Asparagus and Scallion Salad
description: Roasting asparagus and scallion together deepens their flavor, and when paired with whole grains soaked in a garlicky citrus vinaigrette, it all comes together in a salad bursting with umami.

title: A Bold Take on Asparagus, Deep in Its Season
description: The first few weeks of asparagus season are a frenzied time in our house.

title: At the Movies: Our Monsters, Ourselves
description: Summer is fast approaching, and so too is a cavalcade of creeping, slithering, stomping monsters. The nifty independent Colossal, which features a Godzilla-like creature terrorizing Seoul, South Korea, is still in theaters. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 and its science-fiction bestiary opened on Friday, May 5. The latest Alien movie is drooling in the wings, and The Mummy lands in June. The next Planet of the Apes flick arrives in July, and while that franchise may not feature traditional fiends, it finds the monstrous in a familiar place: human beings. Our chief film critics, Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, discuss monsters and wonder how they could be any more frightening than real life.

title: Senate Asks Trump Associates for Records of Communication With Russians
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Intelligence Committee has asked a number of high-profile Trump campaign associates to hand over emails and other records of dealings with Russians as part of its investigation into Russian meddling in the presidential election and is prepared to subpoena those who refuse to cooperate, officials said.

title: Actors Share How They Got the Job
description: Sometimes the hardest part isnt what happens on the set  its landing the role in the first place. Here, a handful of actors gracing the screen this summer talk about how they got a crucial job.

title: A Sample Executive Email Carpet Bomb
description: A letter from Ron Lieber, the Timess Your Money columnist, to executives at Jewel-Osco about a dangerous condition at a grocery store that was affecting neighbors (including his mother).

title: Republicans Disregarded the C.B.O., but It Wont Be Ignored
description: Now that the House has passed its big health care bill, it will find out what that bill could actually do.

title: In Rare Move, Death Sentence in Delhi Gang Rape Case Is Upheld
description: NEW DELHI  Indias Supreme Court upheld on Friday the death sentence for four men who were found guilty of raping and disemboweling a 23-year-old student on a moving bus in 2012, a crime that came to embody the menace lurking in Indias sprawling, chaotic cities.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: This exhibition takes a first shot at the long-overlooked history of 80s American painting and mostly misses its mark. The heady, poly-style energy of the moment is intermittently present, often in works  previously long in storage  by Julian Schnabel, Kathe Burkhart, Moira Dryer and several others. But the show, which closes on May 14 and is limited to the museums collection and its smallest floor of galleries, is confused and timid. Still, dont miss it. So far, its all we have. ROBERTA SMITH

title: Danny DeVito and Christopher Lloyd, Back to the 70s
description: Danny DeVito, whose performance as an antiques dealer in Arthur Millers The Price received a Tony Award nomination for best featured actor this week, said he learned to make the most out of smaller roles long ago, in 1974, during auditions for the film version of One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest. Actors were called back again and again to improvise in character, as psychiatric patients. Mr. DeVito, who had been in a play version of Cuckoos Nest, had to make up his own dialogue while honing facial expressions, body language, even speech patterns.

title: Gabourey Sidibe Talks About This Is Just My Face
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: At Afghanistan-Pakistan Border, Forces Clash and at Least 11 Die
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  At least 11 people were killed and dozens were wounded on Friday in clashes between Afghan and Pakistani forces on the border between the two countries, officials said.

title: Farmers Market Shopping With the Chef Tom Colicchio
description: Before the celebrity chef Tom Colicchio set me straight, I didnt know that ramps grow only in the wild. These garlicky leeks cant be raised in captivity, but must be foraged in rich, moist forests.

title: Is the Met Opera Too Big? And Other Questions as Its Home Turns 50
description: When an opera company moves into a new home, theres always lingering nostalgia for the old one. But fans of the Metropolitan Opera were more than ready to vacate the worn old Met at 39th Street and Broadway for a massive new theater at Lincoln Center. The old Met, I vaguely remember from attending a few performances as a teenager, had fine acoustics and, with its golden horseshoe interior, a kind of faded, dusty grandeur. But backstage resources were woefully inadequate.

title: Triumph, Tragedy and 50,000 Hats: The Met Opera by the Numbers
description: When the Metropolitan Opera moved to Lincoln Center from Broadway at 39th Street in 1966, a subway token cost 20 cents, the Supremess You Cant Hurry Love was at the top of the Billboard charts, and the (pre-miracle) Mets were wrapping up their fifth season. Since then, a lot of sopranos have gone on to meet tragic but beautiful-sounding ends. As the Met prepares to celebrate its 50th anniversary at Lincoln Center with an all-star gala on Sunday, May 7, here is a look at its first half-century in its new home  by the numbers.

title: The Handmaids Tale Episode 4 Recap: Survival Lessons
description: Memory can be a weapon or a wound, its all a matter of perspective. As Offred struggles with nearly two weeks of imprisonment in her room, her memories soon appear to be both. Her memories of the time she, Luke and Hannah went to a carnival prove to be a potent refuge. But Offred tries not to linger in the past, worried it will only compound her fragile mental state. Its too easy to get lost remembering the way things were rather than grappling with the present.

title: Ellsworth Kellys Studio, Just as He Left It
description: Jack Shear lived with Ellsworth Kelly for 32 years, in a house adjacent to the studio where Mr. Kelly worked, in Spencertown, N.Y. After Mr. Kellys death in 2015, Mr. Shear preserved the studio intact, occasionally photographing the space, until Mr. Kellys last canvases were removed to be shown at the Matthew Marks Gallery in New York. I spoke to Mr. Shear about the images he made and his time with the artist.

title: Checking for the Latest Windows 10 Update
description: Q. How do I know if my computer updated itself to the new Creators version of Windows 10 that just came out? I looked in the system information box and it doesnt tell me anything that mentions Creators Update. And are there any problems to expect with this version of Windows 10?

title: You Twist. You Turn. You Move. (And Youre Just the Viewer.)
description: Making art, for the filmmaker and choreographer Lily Baldwin, comes with responsibility. Can I make you feel something? she said. Can I turn you on?

title: Caitlyn Jenners Stolen Red Shoes and Other Revelations
description: When somebody steps into the tabloid glare as willingly and relentlessly as Caitlyn Jenner has, a memoir might seem greedy, or at least redundant. What can be left to overshare? Still, here comes a Jenner memoir with the tattletale title The Secrets of My Life (written with Buzz Bissinger and new at No. 8 in hardcover nonfiction), and it turns out to be plenty revealing. Jenner discusses her ambivalence at becoming a macho role model after winning decathlon gold as Bruce Jenner, along with her early experiences cross-dressing and her attempts to reconcile her gender identity in a succession of doomed marriages. She also relates a funny anecdote about appearing on a Bob Hope television special after the Olympics, for a skit that required dressing in drag. I have to be careful not to show too much enthusiasm, so I play it cool," she remembers. Our wigs and dresses are purposely ridiculous. But the red heels I think not only look good on me but also fit, so I steal them after the show.

title: In Case You Missed It: April's Top Real Estate Stories
description: Catch up on the most popular stories of the month.

title: LeFrak Goes Upscale With Its Latest Tower in Jersey City
description: Standing on a muddy pile of concrete and brick at the edge of a construction site in Jersey City, the developer Richard LeFrak glanced up at the 41-story glass and steel tower rising on the bank of the Hudson River. Somebody once asked me, Whats the best part of the business? This is the best part, he said, referring to the thrill of building a new tower.

title: The Senate Intelligence Committee Letter
description: Lawmakers investigating Russian election meddling wrote to a number of high-profile Trump campaign associates over the past 10 days, asking them to hand over records of communications and dealings with Russian officials and business people.

title: Singing Happy 450th Birthday to Monteverdi
description: It seems logical and simple enough: a performance of Monteverdis 1610 Vespers on Tuesday, the composers 450th birthday. Logical, yes; simple, not entirely.

title: From the London Whale to Wells Fargo, a Bank Regulator Looks Back
description: Thomas J. Currys first week as a federal banking regulator was his worst.

title: At $495, Lonzo Balls ZO2 Sneakers Have Tastemakers Saying No Thanks
description: At the Flight Club sneaker store just south of Union Square on Thursday night, eager customers perused the gleaming shelves, hunting for classic kicks. The big names  the players whose signature shoes are most highly sought  are the ones you would expect: Kevin Durant, LeBron James and, even after all these years, Michael Jordan.

title: Trump Jokes Are at a Record Level on Late Night
description: In December, Stephen Colbert told CBSs John Dickerson in an interview, Now I have no choice but to actually enjoy this incredible gift every day that Mr. Trump will be, referring to the oft-repeated notion that President Trump would be a boon to late-night comedy shows.

title: Daily Report: Uber Stays in the Spotlight
description: Uber, the worlds dominant ride-hailing service, has gone barely a week this year without making headlines. This week has been no exception.

title: Children and Homework
description: To the Editor:

title: The Playlist: LCD Soundsystem and Pokey LaFarge Reckon With What Is Happening
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

title: A Fatal and Fiery Photograph Reawakens Memories of a Soldiers Life
description: In the days after Specialist Hilda Clayton was killed during a training exercise in Afghanistan, an online condolence book sprang up on a website hosted by The Augusta Chronicle, her hometown newspaper in Georgia. Friends and family shared memories of her human rights essay in school, her love of football, and the way she said Mom and Dad Im home when she walked through the door.

title: Ivanka Trump, White House Adviser-in-Training
description: To the Editor:

title: The House Just Passed Its Version of a Health Care Bill. Whats Next?
description: A step-by-step look at what needs to happen before it can become law.

title: White House Proposes Cutting Drug Control Office Funding by 95%
description: WASHINGTON  When he was running for office, Donald J. Trump promised to rid America of the scourge of drugs, vowing to crack down on dealers and invest heavily in programs to get heroin and other opioids off the streets.

title: Worry in Scorched Fort McMurray: How Many Will Walk Away?
description: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta  When a group of Fort McMurray homeowners gathered Wednesday evening for a block party, they had beer, rye whisky and soft drinks. What they didnt have was much of a block.

title: Finding Feists Pleasure and Pain
description: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

title: Michelle Obama Tweets Phone Number of Former White House Staff Member
description: Any White House employee would likely appreciate a public shout-out from the former first lady, but this probably wasnt what Duncan Wolfe had in mind.

title: Some Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
description: On the spring/summer 2017 runways, a handful of models had dark-rimmed eyes so smudged that the phrase next-day makeup didnt do the look justice. The new Chanel makeup artist Cyndle Komarovski calls it an updated version of a smoky eye, and adds that in order to achieve the look at home, all you need are your fingertips. As for why you would want to were taking a cue from the shows, where the rebellious eye makeup added a nice edge to the seasons more delicate and feminine designs. Below, Komarovski walks us through the steps.

title: Minnesota Sees Largest Outbreak of Measles in Almost 30 Years
description: Health officials are grappling with the largest outbreak of measles in Minnesota in almost 30 years, which is mainly sickening young children of Somali immigrants who fell under the sway of anti-vaccination activists.

title: Skeptical Junior and Proud G.O.P. Dad Discuss Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuttlefish Battle
description: A cuttlefish conflict escalated from a visual display of aggression into actual aggression in the first recording of a physical battle between male cuttlefish.

title: A Rare Opportunity to Scream at the Companys Owner
description: As a representative of irate consumers across the country, the Haggler often toils on behalf of people who want nothing more than to find executives and scream in their faces. But that opportunity is rare. Corporate leaders are usually insulated by underlings, which makes their faces difficult to find.

title: Battle of Cuttlefish Caught on Tape
description: Cuttlefish, relatives of octopus and squid, have millions of color cells in their skin, which gives them extraordinary control over their appearance. They are brilliant at camouflage, and they can also create displays to communicate to other cuttlefish.

title: Should Free Markets Govern the Bond Rating Agencies?
description: Theres a lot not to like in the Financial Choice Act, the deregulatory construct put forward by House Republicans on April 28. Dubbed by its creators the alternative to the failed Dodd-Frank Act, it aims to repeal the 2010 laws prohibition against banks engaging in risky trading for their own accounts. It also seeks to gut the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, one of the more effective agencies in Washington.

title: Sterling Jewelers Settles Charges of Bias Against Female Workers
description: Sterling Jewelers has settled federal civil charges accusing it of discriminating against female employees, reaching a deal without having to admit wrongdoing or pay any damages, a win for the company as it faces continuing legal challenges over its pay and promotion practices.

title: Review: Ski End Recalls Fun on the Slopes With Nostalgia
description: After finding themselves locked in an abandoned Vermont ski store, a group of friends has the only reasonable reaction: I guess we live here now, one says.

title: White House Fires Its Chief Usher
description: WASHINGTON  The chief usher at the White House, Angella Reid, who was the second African-American and the first woman to have a job whose title belies its broad responsibilities, was fired this week, administration officials said.

title: Macron Supporters Woo Undecided French Voters
description: Even though Emmanuel Macron is leading in the polls ahead of Frances presidential election on May 7, his supporters are leading a grass-roots effort to prevent voters from abstaining or backing Marine Le Pen, the far-right candidate.

title: Aprils Most Popular Listings
description: All of the most visited listings on The New York Timess Find a Home site last month were in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Our list includes a $50 million penthouse in a Zaha Hadid-designed building, two Brooklyn houses, a financial district loft and an apartment in the East Village.

title: The Necessary Empire
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia  Elections in the Netherlands, France and Germany this year have brought much drama to the old Carolingian core, where Charlemagne founded his empire in the ninth century. This has always been the richest and most strongly institutionalized part of Europe. But should the European Union continue to weaken, the most profound repercussions will be felt farther east and south.

title: 12 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
description: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, were also tooting our own horn here. Well share cant-miss Times articles from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

title: Review: Is Los Elementos Opera? Thats Beside the Point
description: As the reconstituted New York City Opera continues to test its sea legs with a second presentation in its series pera en Espaol, it would be nitpicky and pointless to insist on calling this latest installment pera (o Algo Parecido) en Espaol. But strictly speaking, Los Elementos, by the 18th-century Spanish master Antonio de Literes (which follows the Mexican composer Daniel Catns Florencia en el Amazonas of last June), is only something like an opera.

title: Spring Awakening
description: Benefits were held last week for the Bronx Childrens Museum, Planned Parenthood, Lincoln Center and Pioneer Works.

title: Spring Awakening
description: The spring gala season is in full bloom. Planned Parenthood held its 100th anniversary gala on May 2 at Pier 36. The Bronx Childrens Museum held its inaugural gala on May 2 at Tribeca Rooftop. Lincoln Center held its spring gala on May 2 at Alice Tully Hall. And Pioneer Works held its fourth annual Village Fete on April 30 at its home in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Flooding in New York Shuts Down Roads and Strands Drivers
description: Over the course of just a few hours on Friday, a heavy downpour sent floodwaters through the streets, shutting down roads, stranding motorists, and causing delays on transit systems throughout the New York region.

title: Are These Birds Too Sexy to Survive?
description: In a mossy forest in the western Andes of Ecuador, a small, cocoa-brown bird with a red crown sings from a slim perch. Bip-Bip-WANNGG! It sounds like feedback from an elfin electric guitar. Three rival birds call back in rapid response. These male club-winged manakins are showing off to attract female mates.

title: The Story Was Fine, the Headline Less So
description: When the House of Representatives passed the Republican health care bill Thursday, The New York Times was quick to publish a sidebar that mapped out the bills potential impact on individuals. The winners? The wealthy and upper middle class. The losers? The poor and elderly.

title: What the Republican Health Plan Gets Right
description: Now that the Obamacare replacement bill has passed the House and is moving on to the more centrist Senate, the real debate begins. What is the true purpose of health insurance, and what is our governments goal in ensuring we have it?

title: Florida University to Award Posthumous Degree to Trayvon Martin
description: Trayvon Martin, the Florida teenager whose shooting death by a neighborhood watch volunteer in 2012 prompted a national debate over racial profiling and civil rights, will be awarded a posthumous university degree in aeronautical science that reflects the 17-year-olds dream of becoming a pilot before he was killed.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: Shopping for Outdoor Furniture
description: Choosing outdoor furniture isnt easy. You need something that combines comfort, low maintenance and not just good looks, but the right kind of good looks.

title: Summer Movie Release Schedule 2017
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: Daniel Loebs Pitch for Honeywell May Go Too Far
description: Daniel S. Loeb may be spinning his Honeywell International story a bit too far. The activist investor behind the hedge fund Third Point wants the $100 billion conglomerate to spin off its aerospace unit. That could be an option, but Mr. Loebs pitch that it would increase shareholder value by $20 billion is a stretch.

title: Younger Men, Older Women: A Pairing Becomes More Common
description: The lead-up to the French presidential election has been rife with debates over immigration, terrorism and the European Union, but one nonpolitical factor has fascinated the public in France and abroad: the 24-year age gap between Emmanuel Macron, 39, the candidate who will face off against Marine Le Pen on Sunday, and his wife Brigitte, 64.

title: The Best Places to Move in Retirement? Theyre All Over the Map
description: Whats the best place to live in retirement?

title: Demi Moores Central Park Penthouse Sells for $45 Million
description: The actress Demi Moore finally closed on her triplex penthouse atop the south tower of the landmark San Remo. It took two years to reach a deal, and a $30 million reduction from the original asking price, which had included a two-bedroom maisonette.

title: Why Even a Live-Tweeting Senator Couldnt Stop a Deportation
description: For nearly nine hours on Wednesday, it seemed as though a tweetstorm might be enough to stop a deportation.

title: Debra Winger Comes to Terms With Fame and Age
description: The gaggle of diners glanced up from their table at Locanda Verde in TriBeCa, their eyes out on stalks as they took in the lithe figure heading their way.

title: After Brexit and Trump, Trust Is an Issue With French Polls
description: The mood in France is tense. Europe is on tenterhooks. The world is on edge.

title: Critiquing the Houses Health Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. Case vs. El Chapo: 10,000 Pages and Recordings
description: It has been assumed for months that the prosecution of Joaqun Guzmn Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, would be an undertaking of major proportions.

title: Trumps 2nd Nominee for Army Secretary Withdraws
description: WASHINGTON  Mark E. Green, President Trumps second nominee to be secretary of the Army, withdrew from consideration on Friday, saying in a statement that his nomination had become a distraction because of false and misleading attacks against me.

title: Greg Gianforte on Health Care
description: The Montana candidate talked about the bill to repeal and replace Obamacare.

title: Daliah Lavi, Actress in Both Dramas and Spoofs, Dies at 74
description: Daliah Lavi, an Israeli actress who transitioned from serious parts in foreign cinema and in dramatic films like Lord Jim to lighthearted turns in 1960s spy-movie spoofs like Casino Royale, died on Wednesday at her home in Asheville, N.C. She was 74.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are in Fairfield, Conn., and Garden City, N. Y.

title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: The Fabulous Apple Cash Machine
description: Great things are expected of the most valuable company on the planet.

title: The Wrong Kind of Hot
description: Meryl Streep reads from an essay by Sheila Nevins.

title: For the Couples in This Alexei Ratmansky Ballet, Love Is Not Enough
description: When the choreographer Merce Cunningham was asked in 1991 what his vivid new piece, Neighbors, was about, he replied, Three neighborhood couples, probably from the suburbs. To the next question, Is that all?, he answered, Isnt that enough? Alexei Ratmansky could say much the same about Odessa, his peculiar and marvelous new creation for New York City Ballet, except that his characters arent suburban: Theyre outgoing, intense, sophisticated up to a point, but thoroughly provincial.

title: Mexicos President Vows to Step Up Protections for Journalists
description: MEXICO CITY  Faced with a wave of deadly attacks against journalists, the president of Mexico has vowed to take concrete steps to ensure the safety of journalists in his country, including removing the lead prosecutor responsible for investigating crimes against the freedom of expression.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, the Upper West Side and Harlem.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: To Lift Growth, Janet Yellen Says, Make It Easier for Women to Work
description: In an unusually personal speech, Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said Friday that policies making it easier for women to work could significantly improve the nations economic growth.

title: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
description: 47 times a day.

title: Second Dewey & LeBoeuf Jury May Be Bracing for a Long Deliberation
description: Jury deliberations in the retrial of two former Dewey & LeBoeuf executives on criminal charges arising from the law firms collapse are starting to have a familiar ring.

title: Frances Presidential Election Splinters the Countrys Culturati
description: PARIS  The French comedian Sophia Aram took to the airwaves of one of Frances most popular morning radio shows this week. In the squealy voice of a teenage girl, she cried, I can be against toothbrushes, and against cavities! She then added: Hashtag: NeitherCheeseNorDessert.

title: Being an Old Lady Role Model in Hollywood? Not Easy
description: LOS ANGELES  My first encounter with Sheila Nevins, the president of HBO Documentary Films, was in 2011 at the Sundance Film Festival. Her greeting involved an unprintable rant about thin motel walls and oversexed festivalgoers. I wont lie: It knocked the wind out of me.

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Abortion Foes See Ally in Trump, but Wonder: Will He Go Far Enough?
description: WASHINGTON  There are few constituencies as pleased with President Trumps three and a half months in the White House as the anti-abortion groups that rallied to his side during the 2016 campaign.

title: In Conversation With Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, a feminist icon and mainstay in conversations about womens equality, did not originally intend for her newly released book, Dear Ijeawele; Or, A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions, to be published. It started first as a private letter to a friend who sought Ms. Adichies advice on how to raise her newborn daughter so she doesnt take the kind of nonsense that I took, before being published on her Facebook page and now, finally, in print.

title: Moonlit Handel: This Weeks 8 Best Classical Music Moments
description: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what theyve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

title: 5 Books to Read on Kentucky Derby Day
description: To get a handle on which horse to bet among the 20 entrants in tomorrows Kentucky Derby, turn to The Timess Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert. While they were busy handicapping the field, I was turning, as I usually do at this time of year, to my fairly robust shelf of books about the sport. Assuming youre already familiar with Laura Hillenbrands best-selling Seabiscuit (and if not, then with its film adaptation), here are a handful of other books to read on Derby Day, and during the rest of the Triple Crown season that follows it.

title: G.O.P. House Candidate in Montana Is Caught on Tape Praising Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  When Greg Gianforte, the Republican running for an open House seat in Montana, was asked on Thursday whether he would have supported the bill repealing the Affordable Care Act that passed the House that day, he declined to answer.

title: A Rural Shrine to New Yorks Angels and Gargoyles
description: CHARLOTTEVILLE, N.Y.  New York City has nearly 750 museums and galleries that showcase paintings, dinosaurs, ships, fire trucks and gangsters, to name a few. But when it comes to a certain category of lost New York, the most intriguing collection is in a museum 175 miles away: stone fragments that once adorned city buildings.

title: A U.S. Hiring Plan Falls Short of Reform
description: Infosys, the giant Indian company that supplies American businesses with foreign technology workers, has announced that it will hire 10,000 Americans in the United States in the next two years. This might seem like an early victory in President Trumps Hire American campaign, but its less of a cause for celebration than it appears.

title: Republican Party, Emmanuel Macron: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Yankees Defeat Cubs on Ninth-Inning Home Run by Brett Gardner
description: CHICAGO  Starlin Castro had played enough games at Wrigley Field that he did not need to be at the stadium on Friday to know which way the wind would be blowing.

title: The Color of Protest
description: On Thursday evening, protesters in New York signaled their resistance to President Trump by standing outside the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum, awaiting his first homecoming since taking office, with many wearing white in honor of the suffragist movement. Meanwhile, another form of dissent in a different shade was underway downtown.

title: Leaving College, Going to War
description: Much as the Blue Ridge Mountains towered over campus, Vietnam loomed constantly in the background that spring, exactly 50 years ago, when 264 classmates and I were preparing to graduate from the all-male, almost all-white Washington & Lee University in Lexington, Va. Next door at the Virginia Military Institute, where the graduates would automatically become commissioned officers, Vietnam loomed even larger.

title: Willing to Cook for Strangers, but Guests Are Harder to Find
description: In a penthouse apartment in Manhattans Chinatown on a recent Monday night, Lisa Larsson chopped shiitake mushrooms and looked rather relaxed for someone about to host a 14-person dinner.

title: F.C.C. Will Review Complaints About Colbert Joke, Chairman Says
description: Ajit Pai, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said in a radio interview that his agency was reviewing complaints about a controversial joke told by Stephen Colbert, the CBS late-night host, to determine if further action was warranted.

title: Canada Today: A Fires Lingering Effects, Novelty Socks and a Secretive Tax Program
description: Each week, Canada Today mixes The Timess recent Canada-related coverage with back stories and analysis from our reporters, along with opinions from our readers.

title: Locked Up for Being Poor
description: Maranda Lynn ODonnell, a 22-year-old single mother in Harris County, Tex., was arrested last year for driving without a valid license. The judge set her bail at $2,500. She couldnt afford anything close to that, so she spent three days in jail  even though she posed no risk of skipping town or endangering anyone if she were released.

title: Police Officer Who Fatally Shot 15-Year-Old Texas Boy Is Charged With Murder
description: BALCH SPRINGS, Tex.  A police officer in a Dallas suburb was charged with murder on Friday, six days after he fired his rifle into a car full of teenagers leaving a party, killing a black 15-year-old in the front passenger seat.

title: Macron Campaign Says It Was Target of Massive Hacking Attack
description: PARIS  On the eve of the most consequential French presidential election in decades, the staff of the centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron said late Friday that the campaign had been targeted by a massive and coordinated hacking operation, one with the potential to destabilize the nations democracy before voters go to the polls on Sunday.

title: First, Its Baby Steps for American Pharoahs Progeny
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  A feeling of hope rippled across bluegrass country, and everywhere else in the world of racing, when at 12:30 a.m. on Jan. 3 a mare named Kakadu gave birth to the very first foal by the Triple Crown winner American Pharoah.

title: Rape Charges to Be Dropped in Case Cited by White House as Immigration Issue
description: Prosecutors in Maryland said on Friday that they would drop rape charges against an undocumented immigrant and another high school student, adding a new twist to a case that the White House had held up as evidence of the need to be tough on illegal immigration.

title: To Understand Macrons Economic Vision, Look to Frances Last Chance Students
description: BOBIGNY, France  When Emmanuel Macron rolled out his presidential campaign nearly six months ago, he came to a little-known vocational school in Bobigny, a working-class suburb of Paris. The backdrop was chosen to burnish his image as the candidate who would revive France, especially for young people.

title: I Have No Idea Who Will Win the Kentucky Derby
description: Not long ago I was invited to compile a volume for the Library of America dedicated to the history of horse racing in this country, a sport and a pastime that was well underway before the Declaration of Independence. When I began, I thought it might be helpful to commit to memory the winners of the Kentucky Derby, beginning with Aristides  the speedball chestnut trained by a former slave named Ansel Williamson who bested the legendary racehorse Ten Broeck and 13 other colts in 1875  and going all the way up to last years champion, Nyquist, named for a Swedish hockey star.

title: Adolph Kiefer, a Gold Medal Backstroker in the 1936 Olympics, Dies at 98
description: Adolph Kiefer, a celebrated swimming champion who won gold as a teenager at the 1936 Berlin Olympics and might well have become one of Americas greatest Olympic champions if World War II had not intervened, died on Friday at his home in Wadsworth, Ill. He was 98.

title: Justice Department Expands Its Inquiry Into Ubers Greyball Tool
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An inquiry by the United States Department of Justice into Ubers use of a program to deceive some regulators has expanded.

title: Red Sox, Racism and Adam Jones
description: When I heard that the Baltimore Orioles outfielder Adam Jones was showered with racial epithets by fans at Fenway Park on Monday, it was easy for me to roll my eyes and say, Of course  Boston.

title: Corrections: May 6, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Met Files a Formal Proposal to Charge Admission to Out-of-State Visitors
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has moved one step closer to mandatory admission fees: It filed a formal proposal with the city this week to charge admission to out-of-state visitors, a lawyer revealed in a court hearing on Friday, a controversial idea given that the Met is in part supported by tax dollars and currently has only a suggested entrance fee.

title: A Second Drug Is Approved to Treat A.L.S.
description: A new drug for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrigs disease, was approved on Friday by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Penguins Carry Signs (and Posters and Rugs) of Home on the Road
description: WASHINGTON  Its springtime, and the Penguins are nesting.

title: Judge in Puerto Ricos Debt Lawsuit Handled Major Financial Cases
description: As a federal court judge, Laura Taylor Swain has played a role in two of the highest-profile financial criminal cases of the past decade. Now she will preside over one of the biggest local government financial failure cases ever filed.

title: Fact Check: Rumors, Claims and Context on G.O.P. Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Rumors that the Republican health care bill counts rape, domestic violence and ulcers as uninsurable pre-existing conditions are circulating among opponents of the bill. But these claims are overly simplistic.

title: Vote to Kill Retirement Account Rule Draws Criticism From State-Level Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  An idea to make it easier for Americans to save for retirement that was introduced at the conservative Heritage Foundation is in the cross hairs of a conservative Republican Congress.

title: Paintings by A.R. Penck
description: A.R. Penck, a Neo-Expressionist, painted in East Germany and exhibited in the West under aliases until he was expelled by the government in 1980.

title: A.R. Penck, German Neo-Expressionist of Cold-War Era, Dies at 77
description: A. R. Penck, a leader in the German Neo-Expressionist movement of the 1970s and 80s, which brought a new sense of historical and political drama to figurative painting, died on Tuesday in Zurich. He was 77.

title: Chelsea Bombing Suspect Wants Hospital Interviews Suppressed
description: Ten days after a bomb exploded in Manhattans Chelsea neighborhood in September, injuring more than 30 people, investigators arrived at a hospital surgical intensive care unit in New Jersey to question a man charged in the attack, Ahmad Khan Rahimi.

title: Quotation of the Day: Senate Panel Asks Trump Associates for Communications With Russians
description: I am eager, indeed anxious, to testify in full public session, have requested no immunity and am ready to go.

title: Ivanka Trump Promotes Her Book on Social Media (but Not in the Media)
description: Ivanka Trump will continue to promote her new book on Twitter and Instagram, according to a spokeswoman, weeks after President Trumps adviser and daughter pledged not to draw publicity through a promotional tour or media appearances.

title: Mixed Signals From Trump Worry Pro-Israel Hard-Liners
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump hosted Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, at the White House this week with all the usual bonhomie he displays for foreign leaders. Within hours, he wrote on Twitter that it had been an honor, adding, Hopefully something terrific would come out between the Palestinians & Israel.

title: Puerto Rico: A Debt Problem That Kept Boiling Over
description: It all goes back to 1917.

title: Measure on Pre-existing Conditions Energizes Opposition to Health Bill
description: From the moment the Republican-controlled House of Representatives approved a plan to overhaul the health care system, an onslaught of opposition to the bill has been focused on a single, compact term: pre-existing conditions.

title: Illustrated Books by Peter Spier
description: Peter Spier was a prolific childrens book author and illustrator.

title: Peter Spier, Illustrator of Childrens Books, Dies at 89
description: Peter Spier, an award-winning childrens-book author and illustrator who depicted Noahs biblical journey, told the story of the Erie Canal to the words of the song Low Bridge, Everybody Down and gave voice to the sounds of hundreds of animals like hippos (RRUMMPF) and starlings (FEE-YOU), died on April 27 in Port Jefferson, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Wheres Ivanka When We Need Her?
description: Ivankas got a new female empowerment book, and Dads going to war against women. Great week, gang.

title: Travis dArnaud Joins Many Other Mets on the Disabled List
description: Because of rainy conditions, the Mets did not even play a full game on Thursday in Atlanta, yet they still arrived at Citi Field on Friday with more injury news.

title: What Has Failed in France
description: Americans live to work, while the French work to live. Thats the clich, and its time to retire it. If Emmanuel Macron defeats Marine Le Pen in Sundays election  lets pray the polls are right this time  the message from voters will be: The vacation in Martinique will have to wait. First, wed like to work.

title: 18 Penn State Students Charged in Fraternity Death
description: WASHINGTON  Eighteen students at Penn State University were charged Friday in the death of a 19-year-old sophomore who became drunk and fell repeatedly during a fraternity pledge night in February. Authorities said the student was left overnight, unconscious and obviously injured, by fraternity members who knew he needed help but failed to seek it.

title: Center of a Blowout
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  In yesterdays column, I recommended trusting your brain to fill in the gaps between letters in your crossword. The same thing applies today, except that its a bit harder because today is a day later and Saturday puzzles are that much harder.

title: E.P.A. Chief Recuses Himself From Suits Opposing Obama-Era Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Scott Pruitt, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has removed himself from some of the most contentious cases facing it, including challenges to the Obama administrations Clean Power Plan and a controversial rule related to the Clean Water Act.

title: Boxing Struggles, but It Has a Culture in Its Corner
description: Thirty-four years ago, the boxing promoter Bob Arum was having lunch at the Friars Club with Carlos Barba, the manager of a Newark-based Spanish-language television station that would eventually become the broadcasting giant Univision.

title: Ivanka Trumps Collectible Quotations
description: You might think, spending enough time on Instagram or Pinterest, that Susan Sontags primary contribution to the world was a line of inspirational postcards.

title: Mets Turn to Small Ball to Edge the Marlins
description: The Mets principles for constructing a contender are steadfast and clear. Games are won by batters who can send pitches over the outfield walls and by powerful starters who can employ devastating fastballs to overwhelm opposing hitters.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: The Graduate and the Kentucky Derby
description: The Graduate celebrates an anniversary year. Classic Empire runs the course at Churchill Downs in the first leg of the Triple Crown. And Alec Baldwin and David Letterman watch some movies.

title: Eliud Kipchoge Runs Worlds Fastest Marathon, in Nikes Special Shoes
description: Even in a highly controlled environment, the sub-two-hour marathon remains elusive  just barely.

title: French Voters Express Hope, Anger and Frustration
description: There was at least one big question hanging over the French presidential elections on Sunday that couldve affect the outcome: Would supporters of the defeated far-left candidate Jean-Luc Mlenchon vote for Marine Le Pen or Emmanuel Macron  or abstain altogether?

title: I Never Dreamed of a World in Which I Was Uninsurable
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: Inside VWs Campaign of Trickery
description: This article is adapted from Faster, Higher, Farther: The Volkswagen Scandal by Jack Ewing, the European economics correspondent for The New York Times based in Frankfurt. The book, to be published May 23 by W. W. Norton, reveals new details of a broad conspiracy within Volkswagen to cover up the fact that its cars were designed to deceive pollution regulators.

title: Judy Woodruff, the Woman of the Hour
description: WASHINGTON  It had already been a long day, but Judy Woodruff wasnt in the mood to slow down.

title: U.S. Far-Right Activists Promote Hacking Attack Against Macron
description: After months of trying to move the political needle in favor of Marine Le Pen in the French presidential election, American far-right activists on Saturday threw their weight behind a  hacking attack against her rival, Emmanuel Macron, hoping to cast doubt on an election that is pivotal to France and the wider world.

title: Why I Worship the Weight Watchers Founder Jean Nidetch
description: The day after what I thought was a promising first date with a man I had met online, I received a long text message explaining why exactly he was left with a negative impression of me. The reason was that my online photos were too flattering and didnt fairly show off what my body looked like in person. He used the word deceit. I was, in short, too fat for a second date.

title: How Fidget Spinners Became a Hula Hoop for Generation Z
description: You had never seen or heard of them before. And then suddenly they were everywhere. Whirring on your childrens fingers. Driving their teachers bonkers. Driving you bonkers. Trending on Twitter. Sold out on Amazon. Herein, a primer on how the cheapo gizmo of the moment spiraled out of control:

title: What Its Like to Wear a Three-Armed Jacket
description: Six devotees of Comme des Garons explain their attraction to the fantastical designs of Rei Kawakubo.

title: Molly at the Marriott: Inside Americas Premier Psychedelics Conference
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In a packed, cavernous space one weekend late in April, a crowd of thousands was becoming increasingly amped up. Rainbow hair was commonplace, purple silk pants were sighted, and the smell of marijuana drifted in from a designated smoking area nearby. Audience members watched the stage with avid interest, leaping to occasionally shoeless feet to applaud and cheer.

title: Capturing the Colorful Style of Punjab, India
description: What keeps Mr. Hartman going back  this was his fifth trip  is his fascination with taking pictures of the Nihang Sikhs.This time, he spent most of his days posted outside the Golden Temple, the highest place of pilgrimage in Sikhism, as well as at the train station in Amritsar and the market in Chandigarh.

title: The Wrong Way to Fix Student Debt
description: Tens of millions of Americans together owe more than a trillion dollars in student debt. For the financial health of their households and the entire economy, ensuring a fair and smoothly functioning student loan system is critically important.

title: When That Feisty Neighbor Becomes the President
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  For local officials here, it was one thing to spar with Donald J. Trump, the developer, over the height of his ficus hedges, the crowds at his Elton John concerts and the roar of jet engines over his private club, Mar-a-Lago.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Tech: Uber Under Scrutiny
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Macron Hacking Attack: What We Know and Dont Know
description: The campaign of the French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron was hit on Friday by a large dump of leaked emails and other documents on a file-sharing website.

title: Noisy Construction in the Building
description: Q. A shareholder in our co-op is combining two apartments. For the past six months, the construction has made our lives miserable, tying up the elevator and disrupting any quiet enjoyment on weekdays from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. The board and the managing agent have shrugged off the concerns of shareholders, and we are at our wits end. Is there anything to be done?

title: Meredith Sellers and Michael Pelster: Together, and Not Just Atop Their Class
description: Dr. Meredith Harrison Sellers and Dr. Michael Warren Pelster were married May 6 at St. James Cathedral in Chicago. The Very Rev. Dominic Barrington, an Episcopal priest and dean of the cathedral, performed the ceremony.

title: Farrar Fitzgerald and Thomas Lannon: Searching for Knowledge and Discovering Love
description: Farrar Lee Fitzgerald and Thomas George Lannon are to be married May 7 at the Morton Memorial Library in Rhinecliff, N.Y. The Rev. Richard McKeon Jr., an Episcopal priest, is to officiate.

title: In Venezuelas Chaos, Elites Play a High-Stakes Game for Survival
description: Even as Venezuela sinks into chaos, with clashes between protesters and the police escalating, why have its powerful political and military elites stuck by President Nicols Maduro?

title: Stopwatches and Mint Juleps: 17 Years on the Derby
description: Let me tell you about the Kentucky Derby, one of the longest and most pleasurable days in journalism  modern or otherwise  which Ive been fortunate to cover now for 17 of the past 18 years. (My sole miss, in 2013, was because of my sons first communion. Apparently the Vatican is not aware that something else very important occurs down here in the Commonwealth on the first Saturday of each May.)

title: Variety Puzzle: Split Decisions
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Split Decisions is a nice diversion from a week of crossword puzzles, and it highlights the point I made this week about letting your brain fill in missing information.

title: Hamas Picks Ismail Haniya as Leader as Power Balance Shifts to Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Ismail Haniya, a longtime leader of Hamas in Gaza, was on Saturday officially named the senior leader of the militant group, which has been trying to soften its public image as it jockeys for influence in the Palestinian territories and internationally.

title: 5 Years After Crackdown, an Anti-Kremlin Protest Resumes
description: MOSCOW  Pro-Western liberals, hard-line nationalists, gay-rights activists and other Kremlin opponents gathered in central Moscow on Saturday, seeking to revive a broad-based protest movement against President Vladimir V. Putin that was snuffed out five years ago by mass arrests and stiff jail sentences. The demonstrators chanted the one demand that unites their disparate causes: Russia Without Putin!

title: 85-Year-Old Everest Climber, Trying to Reclaim Record, Dies
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  An octogenarian Nepalese mountaineer who was on a mission to reclaim his title as the oldest climber on Mount Everest died on Saturday afternoon at base camp, government officials said.

title: No District Is Off the Table: Health Vote Could Put House in Play
description: WASHINGTON  In a suburban Chicago district, Kelly Mazeski, a breast cancer survivor, used the day of the vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act to announce her House candidacy, vowing to make Representative Peter Roskam pay for his vote to make Americans pay more and get less for their health care.

title: Health Act Repeal Could Threaten U.S. Job Engine
description: From Akron to Youngstown and Canton to Cleveland, as in cities and towns across the country, workers who once walked out of factories at the end of each shift now stream out of hospitals.

title: France Chooses a Leader, and Takes a Step Into the Unknown
description: PARIS  Frances presidential election on Sunday has already broken all kinds of barriers in a country whose politics seemed frozen for decades. The two candidates are outsiders. The political establishment has been elbowed aside. The tone of the race between the insurgents has shocked many for its raw anger and insolence.

title: Jared Kushners Sister Highlights Family Ties in Pitch to Chinese Investors
description: BEIJING  Jared Kushner has said that he has stepped away from the day-to-day business of his familys real estate company while he serves as a senior adviser to his father-in-law, President Trump.

title: A Mexican Governors Race Carries Presidential Implications
description: The allegations have been flying fast in the bitter campaign to lead Mexicos most populous state. Vote buying. Payoffs. Alliances with rogues. The illegal use of public funds. The flexing of Mafia-style muscle.

title: Fight Brews Over Push to Shield Americans in Warrantless Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  Obscured by the furor over surveillance set off by the investigations into possible Trump campaign coordination with Russia during the election, a major debate over electronic spying that defies the usual partisan factions is quietly taking shape in Congress.

title: In China, Its the Party That Keeps the Boy Band Going
description: BEIJING  The most shared post on Weibo, Chinas Twitter-like social media platform, is not a video of frolicking pandas or President Xi Jinping meeting world leaders, but a teenage boys birthday message:

title: Indonesia Governors Loss Shows Increasing Power of Islamists
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The popular governor was the clear front-runner.

title: Despite the Fading of Star Players, the San Antonio Spurs Future Remains Bright
description: Go ahead, knee-jerk basketball critics, have your doomsday reaction to the San Antonio Spurs stunning loss of Tony Parker. Write them off at your reputational risk.

title: The Mets Wealth of Experience Comes With a Cost
description: The Mets have endured an abundance of injuries in recent years and especially since the start of the 2015 season, when some of their current players first rose to prominence. Despite many physical setbacks, the Mets still reached the 2015 World Series and the 2016 National League wild-card game. But this season, they have sputtered, and injuries are among the reasons.

title: Macron et la dfense de la Rpublique
description: A la prfecture de police de Paris, pendant la crmonie en lhonneur de Xavier Jugel, lofficier de police tu  Paris le mois dernier, son compagnon Etienne Cardiles, accabl de douleur, parla de lamour quils se portaient et adressa ces mots au meurtrier: Vous naurez pas ma haine.

title: How Successful Are Charter Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Meet Dr. Willie Parker, a Southern Christian Abortion Provider
description: No issue in America is more toxic than abortion, and thats partly because it is today so closely associated with religion. While many feminists see abortion as a matter of choice, some Christians see it as murder.

title: When Trump Knows Enough to Stay Home
description: The White House Correspondents Dinner is one of the most repulsive social events in Washington. And you should go once, if you get the chance. You are packed like sardines into the 1950s-style basement ballroom of the Hinckley Hilton (where Ronald Reagan was shot), eating hotel-banquet food and trying to be heard above the din, while the person youre talking to looks over your shoulder for someone more important.

title: A Celebration Turns Into a Somber Recitation of Jailed Turkish Journalists
description: ISTANBUL  With some 163 of their fellow journalists in jail, the men and women of Turkeys news media are understandably fearful. Many of those who avoided prison as part of President Recep Tayyip Erdogans sweeping crackdown on alleged enemies after a July coup attempt have lost their jobs at media outlets taken over by Mr. Erdogans cronies. Some of those still working censor themselves in self-defense.

title: Two Presidential Candidates Stuck in Time
description: In his victory speech early on Nov. 9, President Trump told the nation:

title: Body Cams Work, if Theyre Used Right
description: The police officer who shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards last month in Balch Springs, Tex., was charged with murder on Friday after the Police Department determined from body-camera images and other information that deadly force had been unwarranted. But like most jurisdictions, the Dallas County Sheriffs Office  which is investigating this case  has no written body-cam policy and has made no decisions about making the footage public.

title: Its Not This Muslim Comedians Job to Open Your Mind
description: In November, a few days after the election, I got a call from a television producer, inviting me to be on her popular variety show.

title: Hillary Clintons Absolution
description: One of the best and one of the worst bits of news last week were the same: Hillary Clinton is deep into the writing of another book.

title: Trump: Hazardous to Our Health
description: WASHINGTON  Will Donald Trumps presidency get rotted out?

title: A Late Entry by The Times Into the Fact-Check Biz
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES likes to proclaim its supremacy over all competitors in all categories. But its barely on the scoreboards in the journalistically fashionable realm of fact-checking.

title: Will Bears Ears Be the Next Standing Rock?
description: Rising from the center of the southeastern Utah landscape and visible from every direction are twin buttes so distinctive that in each of the native languages of the region their name is the same: HoonNaqvut, Shash Ja, Kwiyagatu Nukavachi, Ansh An Lashokdiwe, or Bears Ears. For hundreds of generations, native peoples lived in the surrounding deep sandstone canyons, desert mesas  one of the densest and most significant cultural landscapes in the United States.

title: House Republicans Go Off the Cliff
description: OVER the last seven years, the Republican Party has engaged in increasingly elaborate political suicide attempts. The G.O.P. has nominated cranks and erstwhile witches and Todd Akin in winnable Senate races. It has engaged in Somme-esque trench warfare within its own congressional caucus, shut down the government without a strategy for winning anything out of it, and campaigned on a sub-Ayn Randian narrative about the heroic businessman and the mooching 47 percent. And then, after all its prior efforts at seppuku failed, the party nominated Donald Trump for the presidency.

title: To Be Great Again, America Needs Immigrants
description: What makes America great?

title: Dont Let Facebook Make You Miserable
description: IT is now official. Scholars have analyzed the data and confirmed what we already knew in our hearts. Social media is making us miserable.

title: Ai Weiwei: How Censorship Works
description: BEIJING  In the space of a month in 2014, at separate art exhibitions in Beijing and Shanghai that included my work, my name was blotted out  in one case by government officials and by exhibitors themselves in the other case. Some people might take such treatment in stride, as nothing to get huffy about. But as an artist, I view the labels on my work as a measure of the value I have produced  like water-level markers at a riverbank. Other people might just shrug, but I cant. I have no illusions, though, that my unwillingness to shrug affects anyone elses willingness to do so.

title: The House Health Care Disaster Is Really About Taxes
description: I have been a critic of Obamacare since it became law, but the Republican alternative is worse in nearly every way.

title: The Hidden Radicalism of Southern Food
description: OXFORD, Miss.  AMERICA reacts with vigor to the South, for the nation has long recognized its deepest problems here. H. L. Mencken parodied a poverty-wrecked and racism-ruined South as The Sahara of the Bozart. Modern debates about malnutrition have shifted from hunger to obesity. Different Southern deserts have come into focus.

title: Richard Basciano, Times Square Pornography Magnate, Dies at 91
description: Richard Basciano, who fended off decades of legal challenges to preserve Show World as the last outpost of his vast New York pornographic empire, allowing him to reign for a time as the only surviving Times Square sultan of smut, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: New Wave of Nascar Drivers Respects the Past While Charting Its Own Course
description: Four stock-car drivers under the age of 25 gathered in a conference room in New York last week to bat around some of Nascars issues  among them, noticeably smaller crowds and television ratings, and alterations to races to sustain interest.

title: To Build a Contender, Reds Lay a Foundation of Patience
description: Joey Votto tore into a fastball in the first inning Tuesday, driving it 449 feet out to center field, high off the black backdrop at Great American Ball Park. It was his longest home run in years, and it gave his Cincinnati Reds a 3-0 lead  yet the team never scored again and lost by nine runs to the visiting Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Asdrubal Cabreras Thumb Injury Overshadows a Mets Win
description: Mets shortstop Asdrubal Cabrera lay on the outfield grass at Citi Field, clenching his teeth and grabbing his left thumb as a teeming rain fell on him during the third inning of Saturdays game against the Miami Marlins. The weather delayed the game, while Cabrera, who landed awkwardly after diving for a ball, joined the growing group of Mets whose seasons have been interrupted by pain.

title: Puerto Ricans Face Sacrifice Everywhere on an Insolvent Island
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico  Angel Gonzlez, a retired schoolteacher facing a 10 percent cut to his pension, is beginning to wonder whether his three-person household will have to cut back to one cellphone and take turns using it.

title: Michigans Female Hockey Players Support Their Team With Cash and Brooms
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  When it comes to intercollegiate sports, the University of Michigan spares little expense to provide its athletes with world-class facilities.

title: Mourners Celebrate the Lives of 4 Victims of a Queens Fire
description: The mourners arrived at the Queens Village church on Saturday in vans and cars carrying elaborate flower arrangements under a dull gray sky. Some came astride motorcycles, members of a local club in leather jackets who gunned their engines as they rode up.

title: Duality Quality
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  The English language is a quirky one, as anyone in an English as a Second Language class can confirm.

title: Years After Boko Haram Kidnapping, Dozens of Girls Are Freed, Nigeria Says
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Dozens of the nearly 300 schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram militants just over three years ago in the Nigerian village of Chibok have been released as part of an exchange for detained suspects from the militant group, a statement from Nigerias president said early Sunday.

title: 360 View From the Kentucky Derby
description: Step inside Churchill Downs in 360 video and watch scenes from the 143rd Kentucky Derby, a race where thoroughbred horses gallop a mile and a quarter for a $2 million prize.

title: After Late Lead Slips Away, Rangers Lose Game 5 in Overtime
description: OTTAWA  The Rangers let another playoff game slip away here, surrendering a tying goal to a former teammate late in regulation on Saturday and then losing, 5-4, in overtime.

title: At Kentucky Derby, Always Dreaming Produces a Winners Circle Reunion Party
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Both of them were racetrack whiz kids when they met more than two decades ago in New York, where the pedigrees of the horses are dissected like earnings reports, but the blood lines of the humans not so much.

title: Texas Town Gathers to Grieve for Teenager Fatally Shot by Officer
description: MESQUITE, Tex.  Many of those who filed into a church here on Saturday for the funeral of Jordan Edwards wore suits and formal attire. But some of the teenagers  classmates and teammates of Jordan, the unarmed black 15-year-old shot and killed a week ago by a white police officer in nearby Balch Springs  wore white and maroon Skeeter football jerseys.

title: Warren Buffett, at Berkshire Meeting, Condemns Republican Health Care Bill
description: Every year, tens of thousands of investors descend on Omaha to attend the annual meeting of Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate controlled by Warren E. Buffett, and hear directly from the billionaire.

title: Quotation of the Day: Health Act Repeal Would Hurt U.S. Job Engine
description: What is going to happen here is when people dont have access now to care, they will go back to the emergency departments for their primary care, waiting and waiting and waiting.

title: 9 Letters, Starts With C and Ends With D
description: Can anyone think of a word that works for 4-Down  six letters, starts with s, ends in ey?

title: With Power and Precision, Yankees Take Another From the Cubs
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago Cubs pounded baseballs over the wall and had the best starting rotation in baseball last season. But what they did better than any other team was play defense  and they did it by a historic margin.

title: Todd Hill, Venton Jones Jr.
description: Todd Michael Hill and Venton Carlos Jones Jr. were married May 6 at the Black Walnut Point Inn in Tilghman Island, Md. Representative Joaquin Castro of Texas, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

description: Samantha Elena Griffith, a daughter of Jean DeCicco of New York and Jerome S. Griffith of East Hampton, N.Y., and Dodgeville, Wis., was married May 6 to Robert Samuel Shoobs, the son of Diane S. Shoobs and Dr. Michael J. Shoobs of Woodland Park, N.J. The Rev. R. John Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, with Joni Brenner, a rabbinical chaplain, taking part in the ceremony at the Lotte New York Palace Hotel in New York.

Nolan of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., was married May 6 to Frederick Lloyd Baker IV, a son of Mary York Baker and Mr. Baker III of Riverside, Conn. The grooms father, a justice of the peace, officiated at Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn.

description: Samantha Kirsten Ronda and Jake Davis Skinner were married May 6 at Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Luisa Porrata, who was ordained by One Spirit Interfaith Seminary, officiated.

description: Courtney Erin Brein and Eugene Braude were married May 6 at the Down Town Club, an events space in Philadelphia. Rabbi Jeffrey R. Astrachan officiated.

description: Suhagi Mayur Shah and Dr. Nrupen Yogesh Baxi were married May 6 in Asbury Park, N.J. Pandit Omprakash B. Shukla, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Berkeley Oceanfront Hotel.

title: Audrey Levine, Alexander Levine
description: Audrey Rebecca Levine and Alexander Craig Levine were married May 6 at Riverpark, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi Zach Fredman officiated.
