title: Philippines Kills Impeachment Complaint Against Rodrigo Duterte
description: MANILA  Lawmakers in the Philippines on Monday threw out an impeachment complaint against President Rodrigo Duterte that accused him of orchestrating the mass murder of thousands of people in his crackdown on drug use.

title: Louis Vuitton Cruises in Japan
description: Cellphone service was bad in the more remote valleys outside Kyoto, Japan, so there was some question as to when Nicolas Ghesquire, the artistic director of Louis Vuitton, would call. He was meant to be dialing me, at home in New York, to discuss his cruise collection, which he showed at the Miho Museum, about an hours drive east of Kyoto, on Sunday. The museum, designed by I. M. Pei to display the antiquities collection of Mihoko Koyama, is in a far-flung location, tricky to get to and, even among the well-traveled and well-informed, fairly obscure.

title: Macron and Merkel Meet, Pledging to Save European Unity
description: BERLIN  The new French president and the veteran German chancellor used their first engagement on Monday to declare their determination to salvage European unity now that France has beaten back the immediate risk from radical populism, which threatened to undo the European Union itself.

title: Messages to Graduates: Stand Up, Fight Back, Speak Out
description: They may be clich-ridden, funny, witty, inspirational, sad and sometimes angry. One thing they never are is cynical. But whatever their emotional tone, commencement speeches are a guide to life.

title: The Style of Brigitte Macron
description: The wife of Emmanuel Macron, the new president of France, has a personal style not usually associated with first ladies.

title: Brigitte Macron Inaugurates a New Look for France
description: On Sunday, when Brigitte Macron strode up the red carpet at the lyse Palace alongside her husband, Emmanuel Macron, for his inauguration as president of France, it marked not only the official transition of power but also the advent of a new kind of first lady for the nation, and a new kind of political partnership. And it suggested that the Michelle Obama-size hole that has been left in the art of sartorial communications and diplomacy since Americas former first couple left the world stage may be about to be filled  though in an original way.

title: China, Addicted to Bootleg Software, Reels From Ransomware Attack

title: Keep Out the Vote
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Review: U2 Revisits The Joshua Tree in the Here and Now
description: SEATTLE  U2 doesnt want to become an oldies act. But that Irish band couldnt resist booking a tour of quickly sold-out stadium concerts featuring all the songs from its 1987 album, The Joshua Tree  songs that were still both brash and high-minded when U2 performed them here on Sunday night at CenturyLink Field. It was the first United States show, after a premiere in Vancouver, of an extensive world tour. The band will also release elaborate, expanded 30th-anniversary editions of the album.

title: Strict North Carolina Voter ID Law Thwarted After Supreme Court Rejects Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday refused to revive a restrictive North Carolina voting law that a federal appeals court had struck down as an unconstitutional effort to target African-Americans with almost surgical precision.

title: Invaders From the New World
description: Q. There is a long list of invasive species imported to North America, but are there any such exports?

title: How Bees Freshen Up
description: Research shows how honeybees use their hairy legs to clear pollen from their hairy eyes.

title: Why Honeybees Are Good at Grooming (Its All in the Hair)
description: Honeybees are pretty good at what they do, gathering as much as 30 percent of their body weight in protein-rich pollen to bring back to the hive per foraging trip.

title: Horst Mahler, German Holocaust Denier, Is Arrested in Hungary
description: LONDON  An 81-year-old former Marxist urban guerrilla who became a far-right extremist and was sentenced to 10 years in prison for Holocaust denial was arrested in Hungary on Monday after illegally leaving Germany, officials said.

title: Tehran Mayor Quits Race for Iran Presidency
description: TEHRAN  One of the leading hard-line candidates for Irans presidency withdrew from the race on Monday, in a move aimed at consolidating the conservative vote ahead of Fridays election.

title: At 100 or So, She Keeps a Philippine Tattoo Tradition Alive
description: BUSCALAN, Philippines  She wakes up every morning at dawn and mixes an ink out of pine soot and water. She threads a thorn from a bitter citrus tree into a reed, crouches on a three-inch-high stool and, folded up like a cricket, hand-taps tattoos onto the backs, wrists and chests of people who come to see her from as far away as Mexico and Slovenia.

title: I Am Here to Grow A.I.G., Its New C.E.O., Brian Duperreault, Pledges
description: Since being pulled back from the brink in the 2008 financial crisis, American International Group has shrunk significantly. And activist investors have further pushed to split the insurer.

title: Brenda Milner, Eminent Brain Scientist, Is Still Nosy at 98
description: MONTREAL  The driving instructor wiped his brow with a handkerchief, and not just because of the heat. His student  a grown woman, squinting over the dashboard  was ramming the curb in an effort to parallel park.

title: Trumps Youngest Son to Attend Maryland Prep School
description: Barron Trump, the presidents fifth and youngest child, will attend St. Andrews Episcopal, a preparatory school in Potomac, Md., in the fall, affirming the first familys plans to reunite in Washington after living apart since President Trump took office.

title: Salad Days!
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Uber Engineer Barred From Work on Key Self-Driving Technology, Judge Says
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Uber, the ride-hailing company, sidestepped a full shutdown of its self-driving car efforts on Monday when a federal judge stopped short of issuing a temporary injunction against the program.

title: A Qualified Candidate for Head of the W.H.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Stalls Finally Arrive at Canal Street Market
description: When it opened in December, the Canal Street Market offered plenty of shopping options, but the planned food hall was not ready. Now a dozen stands, many selling Asian foods, are operating in the stately building. Theres Uma Temakeria for hand-rolled sushi, Nom Wah Kuai for dumplings and rice bowls, Oppa for Korean barbecue items, Ilili Box for Middle Eastern, Boba Guys for milk teas, and Kuro-Obi by Ippudo New York for ramen. Billys Bakery will have a cart in a few days: Canal Street Market Food Hall, 265 Canal Street (Broadway), 646-694-1655, canalstreet.market.

title: Metropolitan Opera Attendance: Slightly Better, Still Bad
description: When the Metropolitan Opera moved to Lincoln Center in 1966, its general manager worried in a memo that the company had so many subscribers that, for others, it was impossible ever to buy a ticket. As recently as the 1990s, the Met regularly took in more than 90 percent of its potential box-office income.

title: To Make America Great Again, Give Your Kids Chores
description: THE VANISHING AMERICAN ADULT Our Coming-of-Age Crisis  and How to Rebuild a Culture of Self-Reliance By Ben Sasse 306 pp. St. Martins Press. $27.99.

title: Tourists Return to Tunisia, but Slowly
description: Simon Marsov, a 25-year-old management consultant from Moscow, flew to the resort town of Sousse, Tunisia, by the Mediterranean last summer because he wanted to experience a foreign place on the cheap.

title: A Morgan Neville Documentary Will Put an Unfinished Welles Film in Context
description: The Academy Award-winning documentarian Morgan Neville, who took home an Oscar for 20 Feet From Stardom in 2014, is turning his camera to the Hollywood auteur Orson Welles, focusing on the final 15 years of his life.

title: When the Seasoning Is as Important as the Sushi
description: Within these elegant bottles are two artisanal soy sauces: Koikuchi is a traditional style delivering a sharp edge, and Marudai, made from whole soy beans, is richer, rounder and more complex. Shiso soy sauces are brewed in the Shimane Prefecture in southwestern Japan by a family that has been in the business for six generations. Both contain wheat, but they have no additives or preservatives and ferment longer than supermarket brands. Jonathan Blum, a lawyer, imports them. He even describes sushi etiquette on his companys website: Shiso Koikuchi, $16, Marudai, $18 (3.4 ounces each), $30 for both, shisosoy.com.

title: How a Tsunami in Japan Endangered Children in Cambodia
description: The tsunami and nuclear disaster in Fukushima, Japan, now threatens the developing brains of children in Cambodia  but not for reasons that were ever expected.

title: For Cooking Fries, New Shop Says Three Times Is the Charm
description: A few years ago, French fry shops were opening faster than you could say ketchup or mayo? Then the trend subsided, and most disappeared. But they may be coming back. First came Bar  Frites at Le District, and now there is 375 Fries on the Lower East Side, where the potatoes are cooked three times, not the usual two. Theyre steamed, then lightly par-cooked, frozen and finally fried to order in hot oil at 375 degrees, hence the name. The fries emerge properly crisp, well burnished and with a creamy interior. Extravagant nacho, poutine, okonomiyaki and other toppings turn them into a more substantial snack. The shop has Keith Haring-style graffiti and counter seating: 375 Fries, 124 Ludlow Street (Rivington Street), 646-682-7578, 375fries.com.

title: A Showcase Match Falls Flat as Two M.L.S. Linchpins Search for Answers
description: HARRISON, N.J.  In past seasons, Major League Soccer has rolled out the red carpet for matches featuring the Red Bulls and the Los Angeles Galaxy  or, in viewership terms, Market No. 1 versus Market No. 2.

title: Dinner and Two Plays at the New York Theater Workshop
description: The New York Theater Workshop in the East Village presents two plays, Sojourners and Her Portmanteau, by Mfoniso Udofia, in repertory. On weekends through June 4, both plays are performed on the same day, with a dinner break in between. A supper catered by Eat Offbeat, a company that employs refugee women as cooks, is an option for the intermission between shows. There are chicken or vegetarian menus, $20, with edamame salad, cauliflower fritters, Nepali chicken meatballs and vegetable biryani as some items: New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, 212-460-5475, order meal by Thursday before the performance, nytw.org; Eat Offbeat, eatoffbeat.com.

title: Morning Joe Hosts: Conway Said She Needed a Shower After Speaking for Trump
description: The hosts of MSNBCs Morning Joe said on Monday that the White House counselor Kellyanne Conway complained extensively about President Trump in private conversations with them before he was elected.

title: N.B.A. Draft Lottery 2017: Boston Celtics Have Best Chance for Top Pick
description: N.B.A. teams fortunes will rise and fall on Tuesday night with the bounce of a ball  a Ping-Pong ball. Its time once again for the N.B.A. draft lottery.

title: A Smarter Way to Clean Your Home
description: Take this guided tour of your home  from the kitchen and bathroom to the bedroom and living areas  to learn the basic rules of cleaning as well as some tips and short cuts that will help you clean thoroughly and efficiently, starting now.

title: Chuck Davis, Who Brought African Dance Traditions to America, Dies at 80
description: Chuck Davis, a dancer and choreographer widely regarded as Americas foremost master of African dance, died on Sunday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 80.

title: Stroll Through Harlem With Marcus Samuelsson
description: You can now explore Harlem with the chef Marcus Samuelsson. He narrates a tour on a new app created by Detour, a company that specializes in walking tours. Some of the highlights on the Harlem tour are Make My Cake, Sylvias restaurant and Mr. Samuelssons own Streetbird Rotisserie: Savoring Harlem Detour, $4.99 in the App Store and Google Play.

title: Getting Google Cards to Load Again
description: Q. For the past week or so, I keep getting a message on my Android tablet that my Google Now cards failed to load. What causes this and is there a way to fix it?

title: The Campbell Apartment Returns
description: The bar  once the lordly private office of the railroad executive and millionaire John Williams Campbell  has been reborn.

title: Return of the Campbell, an Ornate Grand Central Bar
description: The Campbell Apartment, a soaring, old-fashioned cocktail bar tucked away in an ornate corner of Grand Central Terminal, closed in July to the dismay of many commuters. It will reopen to the public on Wednesday  in triplicate.

title: Daily Report: A Global Attack Hits the Internet. Again.
description: A cyberattack has hit at least 200,000 computers in 150 countries since Friday. More will be known about the extent of the incident as workers who might have missed it on Friday trickle into the office on Monday. But where there have not been major outbreaks might be most telling, at least about who takes computer security seriously.

title: Service to Both Al Qaeda and U.S., With Fate Hanging in the Balance
description: WASHINGTON  No one knew it at the time, but Al Qaedas ability to strike in the West was severely damaged when a skinny onetime altar boy who grew up on Long Island stumbled into a Pakistani checkpoint in 2008, attacked a police officer and was detained.

title: When the Immune System Thwarts Lifesaving Drugs
description: The miracle treatment that should have saved Becka Boscarinos baby boy almost killed him.

title: Sharapova, Foot in Door at Wimbledon, Awaits Approval to Play French Open
description: ROME  Since her return from a 15-month suspension for a positive doping test, Maria Sharapova has had to rely on the generosity of tournament directors for wild-card entries while she rebuilt her ranking. On Monday, she reached a significant milestone en route to guaranteeing her right to compete.

title: Czech Leaders Call to Liquidate Journalists Was a Joke, His Office Says
description: PRAGUE  Milos Zeman, the president of the Czech Republic since 2013, is no stranger to controversy. He once suggested that vegetarians and teetotalers should be put to death  and then added that he was referring to Hitler, who abstained from alcohol and meat. He has referred to news reporters as manure and hyenas. He has called Islam a religion of death.

title: What to Read Before You Watch Jill Soloways New Show I Love Dick
description: I Love Dick, the new Amazon comedy created with Jill Soloway, the Emmy-winning creator of Transparent, comes with a back story that spans two decades. The series is based on the author and filmmaker Chris Krauss autobiographical, experimental first novel of the same name, which has become a feminist cult classic since its publication in 1997. Both versions follow Chris (Kathryn Hahn), a failing filmmaker, as she falls suddenly and completely in love with a mysterious intellectual named Dick (a character inspired, in the book, by the media theorist Dick Hebdige and played, on the show, by Kevin Bacon). In a perverse twist, she is egged on in her obsession by her husband, Dicks colleague Sylvre (Griffin Dunne), who is based on Krauss real-life ex, Sylvre Lotringer. Structured as a series of letters to Dick, the book reads more like an essay on love, art and philosophy than like a traditional novel  which makes it a pretty unlikely candidate for adaptation as a sitcom.

title: Powers Boothe, Actor Known for Deadwood and Other Dark Roles, Dies at 68
description: Powers Boothe, an actor best known for playing dark characters on television shows like Deadwood and in movies like Sin City, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 68.

title: Erasing Stravinsky and Rethinking The Nutcracker: N.Y.U. Announces Ballet Fellowships
description: The Center for Ballet and the Arts at New York University has selected its latest class of fellows in residence, who, during the 2017-18 academic year, will create new dances, write books and, in one case, reconceive The Nutcracker.

title: Syrian Crematory Is Hiding Mass Killings of Prisoners, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The United States accused the Syrian government on Monday of using a crematory to hide mass murders at a prison where thousands are believed to have been summarily executed in the nations civil war.

title: Want to Be Creative on Purpose? Schedule It
description: What if you dont have to be creative to create?

title: Another Twin Peaks Puzzle: How to Make That Cherry Pie
description: NORTH BEND, Wash.  Finding an authentic recipe for Twin Peaks cherry pie is about as easy as figuring out who killed Laura Palmer.

title: What Is Bitcoin? All About the Mysterious Digital Currency
description: Here is a look at the basics behind the electronic currency, which has come under recent scrutiny after hackers behind a global ransomware attack demanded payment in Bitcoin.

title: Medicaid Expansion, Reversed by House, Is Back on Table in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Senate negotiators, meeting stiff resistance to the Houses plans to sharply reduce the scope and reach of Medicaid, are discussing a compromise that would maintain the programs expansion under the Affordable Care Act but subject that larger version of Medicaid to new spending limits.

title: Tips to Keep Your Bag From Taking a Trip Without You
description: Part of what is so frustrating about losing a bag is that so much of the process seems out of the travelers control. But airline cargo professionals say there are a handful of things you can do to lower your chances of having a bag mishandled, or to improve your chances that it will be returned to you if that does happen.

title: Investing in Tech to Tackle an Awful Annoyance: Lost Luggage
description: Sleep versus clean clothes: This was the dilemma faced by Bill Corbett Jr., a public relations firm owner who, after a four-hour flight delay, arrived in Denver around 3:30 in the morning last summer, only to discover that his suitcase had not made it onto the flight.

title: Math Champion Wins With Answer About Pecking Chicks
description: A 13-year-old boy from Texas won a national math competition on Monday with an answer rooted in probabilities  and a dash of farming.

title: More Troops to Afghanistan?
description: To the Editor:

title: Goldman Sachs Sees Big Potential for Fintech in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazil is experiencing a wave of growth in financial technology that will most likely eat into the market share of the countrys huge and long untouchable banks, a new report from Goldman Sachs says.

title: Margarets 4 TV Shows to Watch This Week
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: Margarets 4 TV Shows to Watch This Week
description: Check out these recommendations from Watchings TV critic for May 15-18.

title: Calling for the G.O.P. to Stand Up to Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: Web Defenders Detect Russian Hand in Iranians Hacking Attempt
description: For 18 days last month, a team of computer security experts found themselves engaged in a digital version of hand-to-hand combat with a group of hackers determined to break into the network of a military contractor.

title: Whats the Occasion? Time to Visit Elie Saab
description: Any occasion? a saleswoman in the new two-story Elie Saab boutique on Madison Avenue asks. Elie Saab, the Lebanese designer and Hollywood favorite, is a master of occasion. His designs are recognizable for the way they both cling and drift away, like walking memories.

title: Embracing Rehabilitation
description: To the Editor:

title: American Vistas, Tributes to Awe
description: To the Editor:

title: TK
description: TK

title: Why People Persist in Risky Trading
description: After all the publicity about insider trading the last few years, with headline cases and substantial prison terms meted out to defendants, you might think that people would not try it  or at least do a better job hiding it.

title: Logic Edges Out Chris Stapleton on Billboard Album Chart
description: Another week, another photo finish on the Billboard album chart, with streaming numbers deciding the victor.

title: Crossing Nevada? With New Speed Limit, One Part May Be Just a Blur
description: Shiny new signs posted last week in northern Nevada signal that the state is joining a trend toward higher speed limits for rural highways  motorists can now hit 80 miles per hour on a 130-mile stretch of Interstate 80.

title: Roger Federer Decides to Skip the French Open
description: Roger Federer, who has been in rare form at 35, announced on Monday that he will not play in the French Open, which begins in two weeks, and will instead focus on the grass-court and hardcourt events ahead, including Wimbledon and the United States Open.

title: Transcript of Vinass Sentencing Hearing
description: Judge Nicholas G. Garaufis had to decide how to punish a criminal who had demonstrated a capacity for evil but who had also helped deliver a crushing blow to the terrorists responsible for the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

title: Vinass Army Records
description: Bryant Neal Vinas was given a Chapter 11 discharge  a failure to adapt to the military. His superiors were also concerned that he was suicidal.

title: Court Order in Uber Case
description: Federal court order in Waymos case against Uber.

title: Leave Your Safe Spaces: The 2017 Commencement Address at Hampden-Sydney College
description: This commencement address was delivered on May 14, 2017, to the graduating seniors of Hampden-Sydney College, an all-mens school in southern Virginia.

title: Conan OBrien to Face Joke-Theft Allegations in Court
description: A federal judge has ruled that the late-night host Conan OBrien must head to court to face allegations of joke theft, a rarity in comedy, where accusations often fly but rarely advance past that.

title: Dutch Fertility Doctor Swapped Donors Sperm With His, Lawsuit Claims
description: THE HAGUE  Twelve people who were conceived with sperm from a Dutch fertility center have filed a lawsuit asserting that its longtime director is their biological father, and that over several decades, he swapped donors sperm with his own.

title: Children Playing, Then a Blast: Mortar Round From an Earlier Afghan Battle Kills 5
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The men came back to the mud house, sitting down for lunch and shared grief on Sunday. They had just returned from burying a relative  a police officer who had been killed the night before during a Taliban raid on the local checkpoint.

title: Lets Be Clear: Bad Wines Are Bad Wines, Period
description: If you drink bad wine long enough, will that eventually lead to drinking good wine?

title: Theresa May, Borrowing from Labour, Vows to Extend Protections for Workers
description: LONDON  Since emerging as prime minister from the political wreckage of last years vote to quit the European Union, Theresa May has told Britains voters little about what she believes, aside from stressing her desire for a clean break from the bloc.

title: A Mission to Capture or Kill Joseph Kony Ends, Without Capturing or Killing
description: LILONGWE, Malawi  A contingent of Ugandan and American military officials  and a handful of journalists  will board a plane on Tuesday in the Ugandan city of Entebbe for an approximately two-and-a-half-hour flight.

title: Seaport Lures Guest Chefs for Dinner Series
description: South Street Seaport has been rebranded as Seaport District N.Y.C., and its new Seaport Food Lab will feature guest chefs from June 19 through Oct. 14. Paul Kahan, Cosmo Goss and Erling Wu-Bower from Chicago, Hugh Acheson from Georgia, Alon Shaya from New Orleans, Jessica Koslow from Los Angeles, and the local talent Dale Talde will cook dinners during two-week residences. In addition, the pub Clinton Hall opens Wednesday. The outdoor Garden Bar and the Front Row Food Market, a group of food trucks, start May 24, and a cocktail lounge called Mr. Cannon Speakeasy opens June 19. Eventually, the area will get a David Chang restaurant and one from Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who will also open a market: Seaport Food Lab, 203 Front Street (Beekman Street), tickets $75, Seaport District N.Y.C., 19 Fulton Street (South Street), seaportdistrict.nyc.

title: North Korea, Cyberattack, China: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Thermo Fisher Tests a Deal in Drug Production
description: Thermo Fisher Scientific has started a new experiment with a pricey deal.

title: Digital Insecurity Is the New Normal
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The latest widespread ransomware attack, which has locked up computers in nearly 150 countries, has rightfully captured the worlds attention. But the focus shouldnt be on the scale of the attack and the immediate harm it is causing, or even on the source of the software code that enabled it (a previous attack against the National Security Agency). Whats most important is that British doctors have reverted to pen and paper in the wake of the attacks. Theyve given up on insecure digital technologies in favor of secure but inconvenient analog ones.

title: Red Meat Increases Risk of Dying From 8 Diseases
description: The more red meat you eat, the greater your risk of dying from one of eight diseases, according to a new report.

title: A Strong Case Against a Pesticide Does Not Faze E.P.A. Under Trump
description: Some of the most compelling evidence linking a widely used pesticide to developmental problems in children stems from what scientists call a natural experiment.

title: How to Protect Yourself From Ransomware Attacks
description: A decade-old form of malicious software known as ransomware has been making headlines after cybercriminals hijacked hundreds of thousands of computers worldwide.

title: Indian Girl, 10, Was Raped Repeatedly. Now She May Have to Give Birth.
description: NEW DELHI  A 10-year-old girl who was repeatedly raped by her stepfather, and who is now at least 20 weeks pregnant, may be forced to give birth because of Indias restrictive abortion law.

title: Nattering Nabobs of NAFTA
description: This discussion with David Rennie of The Economist on Trump is pretty scary. To paraphrase an old Brad DeLong line, Trump is more ignorant and impulsive than you can imagine, even taking into account that hes more ignorant and impulsive than you can imagine. How close we came to leaving NAFTA:

title: 4 Plead Guilty in Baruch College Students Hazing Death
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa.  Four men initially charged with murder in the hazing death of a Baruch College freshman pleaded guilty to reduced charges on Monday. The four were involved in a fraternity initiation in which the authorities said the 18-year-old student who died, Chun Hsien Deng, fell unconscious and the other fraternity members delayed seeking medical aid.

title: NBC Woos Advertisers With Megyn Kelly, the New Morning Anchor
description: This week the major networks unveil their offerings for the coming season to advertising buyers in Manhattan. Money, prestige, and cultural import are at stake. Three New York Times media reporters  John Koblin, Michael M. Grynbaum, and Sapna Maheshwari  assess what they saw at Mondays NBCUniversal presentation, which kicked off the television upfronts.

title: Review: Brooklyn Youth Chorus Explores Issues Facing Its Members
description: Viewed from the outside, a choir is a unit, a multitude acting as one. But over the past year, the Brooklyn Youth Chorus has gone out of its way to pry open the unified facade and examine internal differences. On Friday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it presented a resulting work, Silent Voices, an evening-long choral exploration of some of the big issues troubling the ensembles young members: race, gender, socioeconomic inequality and gentrification, among others.

title: 2 Killed as Jet Crashes While Landing at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey
description: A Learjet crashed near Teterboro Airport in New Jersey as it attempted to land on Monday afternoon, killing two crew members and setting several cars and buildings ablaze near the airport, according to officials.

title: 8 Candy-Colored Summer Boots
3 Judges Weigh Trumps Revised Travel Ban, but Keep Their Poker Faces
description: WASHINGTON  Three months after the federal appeals court in California blocked President Trumps first travel ban, a three-judge panel of the same court heard arguments on Monday in a challenge to Mr. Trumps revised ban, this one limiting travel from six predominantly Muslim countries.

title: Jed, a Brand of Eclectic Knitwear
description: The latest collection for the New York-based brand that was introduced last year.

title: Brand to Know: a New York-Based Line of Knits With a Global Influence
description: Entering the designer Jed Krascellas West Village apartment is a bit like walking through the looking glass, or into the Wardrobe. A guest, arriving on a rainy April afternoon, might be offered Turkish delight (From friends in Athens, Krascella says) or delicate candied Violet petals (a drop from the south of France.) Curios fill the walls and shelves: Theres the Florentine tabernacle, dragged back from Tuscany, and Saint Valentines tooth, nestled in a reliquary that Krascella found in Sicily. Iranian pomegranates, dried and hand-painted, sit alongside a selection of scarabs from Luxor, Egypt. I travel a lot, he says. Can you tell?

title: Shaky Coalition in Austria May Give Far-Right Party an Opening
description: BERLIN  Nearly six months after Austria averted a swing to the right by rejecting an extremist candidate for president, the country appeared poised to clear a path for the far-right Freedom Party to enter into power as the current government teetered on the verge of collapse.

title: Review: Decades Later, a Classic Concert Gets a Redo
description: In 1961, what was then called the New School Concerts presented a program of new music from Europe. The event was troubled by calamities. Crucial percussion instruments arrived broken; New York was clobbered by a massive snowstorm the morning of the performance.

title: Review: She Brings Stories of Sexual Violence to the Stage
description: In She, described as a choreoplay by the dancer and choreographer Jinah Parker, four women detail their experience of sexual violence as female dancers swirl around them in gestures of support and assault. With a script influenced by The Vagina Monologues and for colored girls who have considered suicide when the rainbow is enuf, She feels urgent in its aims, if less assured in its execution.

title: No More Gang Rape Scenes in Ballets, Please
description: When the curtain went down on Alexei Ratmanskys dense, complicated new work for New York City Ballet last weekend, the end of a long Sunday matinee, my friend and I turned to each other, not sure what to think.

title: Under Fire, Climate Scientists Unite With Lawyers to Fight Back
description: Lawyers and scientists do not always get along, but some are now finding common cause in an effort to defend the integrity of science  especially climate science  in government and academia.

title: Terrence McNally and Carmen Jones: Classic Stage Companys New Season
description: Terrence McNallys new play Fire and Air, about the ballet titan Sergei Diaghilev and his turbulent relationship with the dancer Vaslav Nijinsky, will have its premiere as part of Classic Stage Companys 50th anniversary season.

title: A Whistle-Blower Tells of Health Insurers Bilking Medicare
description: When Medicare was facing an impossible $13 trillion funding gap, Congress opted for a bold fix: It handed over part of the program to insurance companies, expecting them to provide better care at a lower cost. The new program was named Medicare Advantage.

title: Trump, North Korea, Ransomware: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Trump, About to Visit Saudi Arabia, Is Urged to Help Yemen
description: GENEVA  As President Trump prepares for his first overseas trip this week, his decision to make Saudi Arabia his first stop is prompting urgent appeals from humanitarian agencies to assist in the crisis in neighboring Yemen, which is careening toward a catastrophe.

title: Suiting Up for a Ceremony, Derek Jeter Swings for the Fences
description: Unlike basketball and football players, few baseball players are known for their sense of style. There is no red carpet with a step and repeat laid out for their events. Name one with a popular fashion brand collaboration. Vogue does not coax Yankees or Red Sox onto its pages to be photographed with the latest top model. They are rarely seen in the front rows of fashion shows.

title: Trump Revealed Highly Classified Intelligence to Russia, in Break With Ally, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump boasted about highly classified intelligence in a meeting with the Russian foreign minister and ambassador last week, providing details that could expose the source of the information and the manner in which it was collected, a current and a former American government official said Monday.

title: Trump to Expand Funding Ban Tied to Abortion Overseas
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration said on Monday it would vastly expand the so-called global gag rule that withholds American aid from health organizations worldwide that provide or even discuss abortion in family planning. The new policy could disrupt hundreds of clinics in Africa and around the world that fight AIDS and malaria.

title: Digging to the Roots of Maurice Sendaks Vision
description: THERES A MYSTERY THEREThe Primal Vision of Maurice SendakBy Jonathan CottIllustrated. 242 pages. Doubleday. $30.

title: Beheadings and Vengeance: A Cycle of Killing on a Border in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI  The family of Subedar Paramjit Singh, one of two Indian soldiers who were beheaded this month while patrolling the de facto border between India and Pakistan, wanted to see him one more time before consigning his body to the flames.

title: Cheers and Boos at Commencement Speeches
description: From Will Ferrell singing to the education secretary, Betsy DeVos, getting disapproval, 2017 commencement speeches ran the gamut.

title: Steve Palermo, Umpire Whose Career Was Ended by a Bullet, Dies at 67
description: Steve Palermo, whose career as a major league baseball umpire ended when he was shot and partly paralyzed in 1991 after intervening in a robbery outside a Dallas restaurant, died on Sunday in Overland Park, Kan. He was 67.

title: Shell Take Snackhattan
description: Dear Diary:

title: Tulsa Officer Cites Her Training in Testimony About Fatal Shooting
description: TULSA, Okla.  Betty Jo Shelby, the white Tulsa police officer charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of an unarmed black driver in September, testified on Monday that during the encounter, she relied on her training in how to deal with potentially dangerous suspects.

title: Thomas V. Daily, Bishop With Legacy Tarnished by Response to Abuse, Dies at 89
description: Thomas V. Daily, the bishop emeritus of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, who raised tens of millions of dollars to repair schools and churches but whose last years were marred by criticism of how he had handled the churchs sexual abuse scandals in Boston and Brooklyn, died early Monday in Queens. He was 89.

title: Trumps Fraudulent Voter-Fraud Commission
description: President Trumps repeated claim  that millions of noncitizens voted illegally in the 2016 election has always been transparently self-serving  a desperate attempt to soothe his damaged ego and explain how he could have lost the popular vote to Hillary Clinton by almost three million votes.

title: In Ransomware Attack, Where Does Microsofts Responsibility Lie?
description: SEATTLE  When malicious software first became a serious problem on the internet about 15 years ago, most people agreed that the biggest villain, after the authors of the damaging code, was Microsoft.

title: Police Officer, Combat Veteran, Muslim and J.F.K. Detainee
description: Syed Ali is an American citizen, an officer in the New York Police Department, a combat veteran and a major in the United States Army Reserve. But none of that made a difference at passport control last month when he arrived at Kennedy Airport on an evening flight from Istanbul.

title: Fact-Checking a Moguls Claims About Avocado Toast, Millennials and Home Buying
description: Millennials have enough problems as it is. Must they give up their avocado toast, too?

title: We Have to Repudiate It: A City Confronts White Nationalist Protests
description: The demonstrators assembled on Saturday night, torches in hand, under the statue of Robert E. Lee that Charlottesville, Va., has decided to sell.

title: On the N.H.L.s Playoff Ice, Injuries Are Risen Above
description: During the N.H.L. playoffs, Ottawa defenseman Erik Karlsson has played more minutes than anyone else  with two stress fractures in his foot.

title: 20 Years On, Amazon and Jeff Bezos Prove Naysayers Wrong
description: Twenty years ago this week, Amazon.com went public.

title: North Korea Missile Test Appears to Tiptoe Over a U.S. Tripwire
description: For months, Washington has been bracing for North Korea to test an intercontinental ballistic missile, waiting to see how close it could get to the United States and how aggressively President Trump should react.

title: East Harlem Elementary Principal Is Out After a Yearlong Fight
description: After a yearlong civil war inside Central Park East I, a progressive elementary school in East Harlem, the schools embattled principal has stepped aside, New York Citys Education Department said on Monday, handing a victory to parents who had accused her of seeking to dismantle the schools traditions.

title: In One-Party Alabama, Senate Primary Sinks Into Swamp
description: HOOVER, Ala.  The suburban Birmingham headquarters of the Alabama Republican Party is something of a shrine to the one-party rule that is a political fact of life here. But on Monday afternoon, the headquarters Chairmans Parlor showcased the less tidy side of the partys total grip on power: The fiercest attacks now come during the Republican primary, which is tantamount to the general election.

title: When the World Is Led by a Child
description: At certain times Donald Trump has seemed like a budding authoritarian, a corrupt Nixon, a rabble-rousing populist or a big business corporatist.

title: Hillary Clinton Starts Onward Together, a New Political Group
description: Hillary Clinton on Monday announced the launch of Onward Together, a new political group aimed at advancing progressive causes by harnessing grass-roots opposition to President Trumps policies.

title: Warriors Zaza Pachulia Draws Spurs Ire Over Key Play
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  It is safe to assume that Zaza Pachulia, the starting center for the Golden State Warriors, never expected be the source of so much debate at this stage of the N.B.A. playoffs. On a team full of scoring savants, Pachulia is a low-post plodder. It must feel a little like being the only vegetarian at a ribs joint. But he does his job, and it is not always elegant.

title: In Computer Attacks, Clues Point to Frequent Culprit: North Korea
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intelligence officials and private security experts say that new digital clues point to North Korean-linked hackers as likely suspects in the sweeping ransomware attacks that have crippled computer systems around the world.

title: Parties Tussle Over Legality of Stipends Given to New York Senators
description: ALBANY  As the latest ethical scandal swirled around the State Capitol, New York lawmakers on Monday faced a barrage of questions about the propriety, and even legality, of a raft of questionable stipends given to seven senators.

title: Before Trumps Visit to Israel, Small Issues Prove Thorniest
description: WASHINGTON  The White House ran into static with the Israelis on Monday on a series of small, but sensitive, diplomatic issues, ranging from the legal status of the Western Wall to President Trumps repeated promise to move the American Embassy.

title: Gunmen Kill Prominent Mexican Journalist Who Covered Drug Cartels
description: MEXICO CITY  A veteran journalist who had chronicled the bloody conflicts among rival drug cartels in his home state, Sinaloa, and the culture of violence they inflicted on the broader society, was killed by gunmen on Monday near the newspaper that he had co-founded, the authorities said.

title: Quotation of the Day: In Computer Attacks, Clues Point to Frequent Culprit: North Korea
description: This is what happens when you give a tiny little criminal a weapon of mass destruction. This will only go bigger.

title: Brad Grey, Former Chairman of Paramount Pictures, Dies at 59
description: LOS ANGELES  Brad Grey, who rose from blue-collar roots in New York to the pinnacle of Hollywood, where he was the chairman of Paramount Pictures for a dozen years and played a pivotal role in the creation of seminal television hits like The Sopranos, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 59.

title: Get Dog-Tired
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  When we last saw Bruce Haight, he was busy convincing himself that the alphabet only has seven letters, but today he mixes us all up. If you love anagrams, however, youll like this one.

title: Review: Venus Recalls a Womans Fortune, and Her Ruin
description: Attention, please, those of you whose greatest ambition is to acquire the traffic-stopping body of Kim Kardashian. There is a less drastic alternative to costly and dangerous buttocks implants.

title: Texas Seeks Medicaid Money It Gave Up Over Planned Parenthood Ban
description: Four years after Texas gave up millions of dollars in federal Medicaid funds so it could ban Planned Parenthood from participating in a family planning program for low-income women, the state is asking the Trump administration for the money back.

title: After Heavy Bidding, a Brancusi Head Sells for $57.4 Million at Christies
description: Just when it looked as if some in the crowd at Christies might nod off during a slow-going  albeit solid  auction of Impressionist and Modern works Monday evening, a bronze female head by Constantin Brancusi injected a powerful dose of excitement into the proceedings. The work sold for $57.4 million with fees after nine minutes of vigorous competition from at least five bidders in the room and on the phones.

title: How Government Secrets Are Declassified and Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON  The news that President Trump disclosed highly classified information about the Islamic State during a meeting with Russian officials, jeopardizing an allys intelligence source, has raised interest in legal issues surrounding disclosures of classified information.

title: Who Are The Shadow Brokers?
description: A National Security Agency hacking tool leaked in April by an elite group called the Shadow Brokers has now been used in a cyberattack on computers in more than 150 countries. Intelligence officials say North Korean-linked hackers are likely suspects.

title: De Blasio Raises More Than G.O.P. Challenger for the First Time
description: Seeking re-election without a strong Democratic primary opponent, Mayor Bill de Blasio has for the first time raised more money than his best-funded Republican challenger, Paul J. Massey Jr., according to the latest campaign finance records, which were disclosed on Monday.

title: Asdrubal Cabreras Thumb Injury Is a Lingering Problem for the Mets
description: PHOENIX  The steady trickle of injuries plaguing the Mets this year has given them plenty of difficult decisions. Particularly tricky are players with midlevel, nagging injuries: Should the Mets put the player on the 10-day disabled list or give him a few days of rest and hope it improves?

title: Better Call Saul Season 3, Episode 6: Brick by Brick
description: With your indulgence, let me start on a somewhat pedantic note. The man who appeared in that exuberant TV ad for TV ads at the end of this episode was Saul Goodman, a guy who should not be confused with Saul Goodman. Saul Goodman is an attorney with a side order of huckster. With Saul Goodman, the huckster is the whole meal. The two should not be confused.

description: Name Jamie Wolfond

title: Hedge Fund Managers Dont Always Beat the Market, but They Still Make Billions
description: Good performance, mediocre results or even downright ugly returns. When it comes to hedge funds, it scarcely matters. Even as some investors begin to sour on these high-priced stock pickers, the top fund managers still haul in enormous paychecks.

title: Arab TV Series Dramatizes Life Under ISIS
description: A mother travels to Syria to find her son after he ran away to join the Islamic State. A Christian renounces her faith and plots to blow up a church. A black-clad matron tells teenage girls to rest up before they are raped by extremist fighters.

description: In Tracy Morgan: Staying Alive, Mr. Morgan performs his first special since his 2014 car crash. And in the series finale of Through the Wormhole With Morgan Freeman, Mr. Freeman tackles gun violence.

Math Problem
description: The 13-year-old in this photo won a national math competition on Monday by answering the question below in less than a second. Can you solve it?

title: Australian Refugee Camp on Manus Island Is Closing, Detainees Say
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The refugees and asylum seekers had been waiting in the detention camp in the hope of a fresh start in Australia, or perhaps some other country. But on Monday, some of the residents said, they were told to prepare for a different outcome  the imminent shutdown of the camp.

title: Right and Left React to Trumps Sharing Classified Information With Russia, and More
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and the left that you might not have seen.

title: Susan Faludi: In My World, Photographs Lie
description: Susan Faludis latest book, about her photographer fathers transition to a woman, originally had no photos. In time she realized that images are moments carved disingenuously out of continuous experience, but they can be redeemed by age.

title: Charlie Company and the Small-Unit War
description: Operation Cedar Falls. Operation Junction City. Operation Scotland. With nearly 500,000 American troops in country by the close of the year, 1967 is often remembered as the period when Gen. William Westmoreland took the war to the enemy in major operations across the length and breadth of South Vietnam. From War Zone C to Dak To to Con Thien, the result was heavy fighting in major battles that dominated the headlines back home. That year American forces had 9,377 dead and 12,716 wounded, almost double the numbers of the previous year.

title: Agreements That Lock Up Workers, Legally
description: The economy thrives when businesses compete with each other for workers and customers. That is hardly a new idea, but it bears repeating as companies increasingly use noncompete agreements to lock up employees and prevent them from taking better-paying or more fulfilling jobs.

title: How Trump Hurts the Spying Business
description: The man seated across from me had been a spy for the United States for several decades. Recruited by a C.I.A. officer, this man, at great risk to his and his familys lives, had provided critically important intelligence that formed the basis of innumerable raw intelligence reports, some of which found their way into the Presidents Daily Brief.

title: Muscovites Fight for a Slum of Their Own
description: On the face of it, anyone living in one of the ubiquitous five-story tenements ringing central Moscow should be happy to move out. Hurriedly thrown up to ease the chronic housing shortage after World War II and designed to last no more than 25 years, the shoddy, crooked, crumbling buildings with their tiny apartments are known as khrushchevki, a play on Nikita Khrushchev, the Soviet leader under whom most of them were built, and trushchyoby, Russian for slums. Yet when Moscows municipal government offered residents equivalent apartments in modern buildings farther from town so that thousands of the tenements could be razed, they promptly took to the streets.

title: How Democrats Can Get Their Mojo Back
description: The great new dividing line in American life is the four-year college degree. The line runs through virtually every part of society.

title: Susan Faludi: In My World, Photographs Lie
description: My father, Stefanie Faludi, died just before dawn on May 14, 2015, in the womans ward of a Budapest hospital, at the age of 87. It had been 11 years since her sex reassignment surgery and, not coincidentally, 11 years since our reunion after a quarter-century of estrangement. In the days after her death, I combed through her house, a forbidding concrete bunker perched high in the Buda Hills, inspecting the many closets, cabinets and storerooms shed kept locked. I was looking for a clue to a life just passed, an inkling of who she was. Under the eaves behind two sets of deadbolts, and tucked inside steel cases, storage bins and acetate envelopes, I discovered an arsenal of cameras  Hasselblad, Rolleiflex, Leica, Olympus, a bellows camera built into a mahogany frame  lenses, cables, filters, tripods, along with developing sinks and processing trays, a wall-mounted enlarger and giant drum print-dryer, relics of her commercial photo business in Manhattan in the 1980s, her documentary work of the Brazilian interior in the 1950s, and her first attempts at filmmaking in Hungary in the 1930s. And, in acetate envelopes and slide trays, thousands of Tri-X negatives and Ektachrome slides, along with contact sheets and prints, chronicling year by year and in meticulous order, the minutiae of Faludi family life. That is: my life, and my life with my father.

title: Questions for: How Google Took Over the Classroom
description: Article: How Google Took Over the Classroom

title: Mets Pitching Problems Are Laid Bare in Loss to Diamondbacks
description: PHOENIX  If the Mets believe they can compete for a title in 2017, something may need to change. After Mondays 7-3 loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks, their fifth straight defeat, the Mets glaring flaws were exposed yet again.

title: Hyundai Whistle-Blower, in Rarity for South Korea, Prompts Recall
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Gwang-ho, an automotive engineer, did something last year that many South Koreans saw as an act of betrayal: He became a whistle-blower.

title: Inside an Abandoned Airport in Greece, a Refugee Camp
description: Asylum seekers live inside the arrivals terminal of a decaying airport in Greece.

title: Should Students Get Grades 13 and 14 Free of Charge?
description: Free college is a lovely, sensible notion  but countries seem capable of embracing it only when enough of their top earners pay 50 percent or more of their income in taxes. In the United States, New York is the sole state to have taken the step of offering to cover tuition at all its public colleges and universities. And even this new benefit, the Excelsior Scholarship, which Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed into law last month, helps only a small fraction of the states residents  households earning less than $125,000 that are not already covered by financial aid  and their grants convert into loans unless graduates both live and work in the state for as many years as they benefited from the program. It also does not cover living costs.

title: The Genetics of Pooched-Out Pooches
description: What lengths will a dog go to for a bite of sausage? Last November, scientists at the University of Cambridge in Britain persuaded several dozen pet owners to bring their Labrador retrievers to its veterinary school for a true test of will. Inside a mostly empty white room, a research associate let each dog sniff a hot dog before demonstratively placing it inside a small plastic hamster cage on the floor and sealing it shut with black duct tape. Some of the Labs showed only passing interest in the trapped sausage and spent more time exploring the rest of the room. But others stayed laser-focused on the treat. One in particular, a black Labrador named Ash, went into a tizzy, banging the cage around and not giving up until he pried the tape loose with his teeth and ate the hot dog.

title: From Wells Fargo to Fyre Festival, the Scam Economy Is Entering Its Baroque Phase
description: Over the past few decades, as the regulatory and legal protections that once shielded consumers, workers and investors have been systematically rolled back, the character of American business has noticeably changed. Year by year, weve reverted toward a 19th-century style of capitalism, one in which the caveat is almost always up to the emptor. Weve moved from an industrial economy to a consumer economy to a service economy to an information economy to what you might call a flagrant-exploitation economy  one in which branding and storytelling have replaced advertising and possibly even reality. Its not just that were being sold the sizzle more than the steak. Its that were being sold the sizzle instead of and at the expense of the steak.

title: What Animals Taught Me About Being Human
description: Long ago, when I was 9 or 10, I wrote a school essay on what I wanted to be when I grew up. Ill be an artist, and Ill keep a pet otter, I announced confidently, before adding, as long as the otter is happy. When I got back my exercise book, my teacher had commented, But how can you tell if an otter is happy? I boiled with indignation. Surely, I thought, otters would be happy if they had a soft place to sleep, could play, go exploring, make a friend (that would be me) and swim around in rivers catching fish. The fish were my only concession to the notion that an otters needs might not match my own. It never occurred to me that I might not understand the things an otter wanted, or understand much of what an otter might be. I thought animals were just like me.

title: New Sentences: From Veep, Season 6, Episode 2
description: One great joy of the Scottish director Armando Iannuccis string of political satires  the BBC series The Thick of It, the film In the Loop and the HBO series Veep, now in its sixth season  is its characters relationship with language. Not one of them, including great statesmen and professional spokespeople, seems capable of making a well-formed, nonmortifying statement in public. But behind closed doors, where theyre free to express their endless contempt for one another, their speech is athletic and limber and just about symphonically profane. Theyre masters of high-speed sophistry and self-serving rationalizations, and they threaten one another as if the power of threats lies mainly in how elegantly expressed they are  as when the former president in Veep, Selina Meyer, tells a congressman, I will destroy you in ways that are so creative, they will honor me for it at the Kennedy Center.

title: I Saw the Decline of a Democracy
description: What my reporting in Turkey told me about how its autocratic president is seizing power.

title: On the Water: 10 Favorite Places on European Rivers, Lakes and Coastlines
description: The rugged coast of northern Italy, a vintage British pleasure pier, winding Norwegian fjords and a jewel box of a lake district in the Croatian countryside: Our writers share their favorite watery places in Europe.

title: The Mystery of the Wasting House-Cats
description: Most days, the back room of the Animal Endocrine Clinic in Manhattan is home to half a dozen cats convalescing in feline luxury. They lounge in their own individual condos, each equipped with a plush bed, a raised perch and a cozy box for hiding. Classical music plinks softly from speakers overhead. A television plays cat-friendly videos  birds chirping, squirrels scampering. Patients can also tune in to the live version: A seed-stuffed bird feeder hangs directly outside each window.

title: 1967: Accord Reached to Cut Tariffs by Average of a Third
description: GENEVA  The United States and the worlds major trading nations reached agreement tonight in the Kennedy Round of talks on cutting tariffs and promoting trade worth billions of dollars a year. The announcement was made by George Weaver, U.S. under-secretary of commerce, as he left a meeting of the nations involved to iron out the final details. Experts say the reductions in customs duties will average 33 to 35 percent in 80-odd nations. This was less than the 50 percent slash that had been sought, but more than had ever before been achieved in tariff negotiations.

description: With extreme pain, frequent hospitalizations and major complications, sickle cell anemia can affect all aspects of life. Six men and women speak about living with this condition.

description: Another day, another brand being called out on social media for a misbegotten product.

title: The 10 Best Things We Saw at the Venice Biennale
description: Mark Bradfords installation at the United States pavilion begins with Hephaestus, a heroic poem written by the artist and drawn from Greek mythology as well as from his own biography. It is installed outside of the Jeffersonian-style building on cement-board slabs. Bradford then forces visitors to enter the building from the left rather than through the imposing front door marked with columns. I dont think progressive ideas ever come through the front door, Bradford says. We always come through the side door, through the window, through the tunnel we bore, we struggle for our identities.

title: Bill Cosby Says He Will Not Testify at His Criminal Trial
description: Bill Cosby will not testify at his trial next month in Pennsylvania on sexual-assault charges, he said in a radio interview that aired on Tuesday.

title: Steroid Shots Do Little for Knee Pain of Arthritis
description: Doctors often prescribe steroid injections for the pain of knee arthritis, but a rigorous trial has found they work no better than a placebo.

title: How to Keep Your Valuables Safe on Vacation
description: Did you know that you may be more susceptible to having your valuables, such as watches and cellphones, stolen when youre on vacation? So many things are new on a vacation, and while youre taking it all in, your guard drops a bit, leaving you vulnerable to theft, said Matt Dumpert, a senior director at Kroll, a security consulting company based in New York.

title: Twin Peaks Season 2, Episode 22: When You See Me Again, It Wont Be Me
description: In the run-up to the new season of Twin Peaks, Noel Murray is helping to refresh our memory with a series of recaps covering the first two seasons. (Its only been 26 years!) The new season debuts on May 21 on Showtime.

title: For a Village in Demand, Its Lights, Camera, Inconvenience
description: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  In this village perched along the Hudson River, boys pedal up to one of the spots downtown for drinks and snacks after school. At a pizza parlor, the owner lets a regular customer walk off with a plain slice with the understanding that she will pay the next time she comes in. Around the corner, the hardware store has set up its barbecue grills for sale on the sidewalk, welcoming springs arrival.

title: India Allows Abortion for 10-Year-Old Rape Victim
description: NEW DELHI  An Indian court ruled on Tuesday that doctors were free to carry out an abortion on a 10-year-old girl who was raped and impregnated by her stepfather.

title: David Letterman Wins Mark Twain Prize for American Humor
description: Like Mark Twain, David Letterman distinguished himself as a cockeyed, deadpan observer of American behavior and, later in life, for his prodigious and distinctive facial hair. Now the two satirists share a further connection: On Tuesday, Mr. Letterman was named the next recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, the award granted annually by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: An Iconic American Painter, Re-examined Through Poetry
description: In the last years of Philip Gustons life, the painter found comfort in the melancholia of T.S. Eliot, especially his Four Quartets. At least that is how his daughter, Musa Mayer, remembers it. I think he connected to the way Eliot was able to find meaning in the darkness, Mayer says. Of course, throughout his life, he always felt a certain allegiance to poetry. I think its because of the metaphysical aspect of poetry, the way in which symbols and imagery are used to suggest something larger, something deeper.
