description: Silvia Szu-Sien Bernardini and Anthony Vu Lee were married May 20 at the Stone House at Stirling Ridge in Warren, N.J. Richard J. Colonna, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Margot Gianis, Brendan Mooney
description: Margot Anne Gianis, a daughter of Elizabeth S. Gianis and Dr. John T. Gianis Jr. of Morristown, N.J., was married May 20 to Robert Brendan Mooney, the son of Elizabeth C. FitzGerald of Falmouth, Me., and Christopher G. Mooney of Bradenton, Fla. The Rev. William H. Stone III, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N.J.

title: Gigi Burris, Evan OHara
description: Virginia Allison Burris and Evan OHara were married May 20 at the Standard, East Village hotel in New York. The Rev. Blaze Robertson, a Pentecostal minister, officiated.

title: Lauren Levy, Eric Goodman
description: Cantor Lauren Beth Levy and Dr. Eric Robert Goodman are to be married May 21 at the Grounds for Sculpture, a sculpture park and museum in Hamilton Township, N.J. Cantor Benjie Schiller is to officiate.

title: Morgan Parker, Bernard Fraga
description: Morgan Kuzma Parker and Bernard Luis Fraga were married May 20 at St. Paul Catholic Center in Bloomington, Ind. The Rev. Steve Sallis, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Brier, Kathryn Hindmand
description: Jennifer Meredith Brier and Kathryn Jean Hindmand were married May 20 in Brooklyn. J. Bob Alotta, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the BRIC Arts Media House.

title: Michelle Ker, Jacob Locke
description: Michelle Ker and Jacob Daniel Locke were married May 15 at the Superior Court Marriage Bureau in Washington. Paul Trudeau, the branch chief for the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated.

title: Sarah Krinsky, Daniel Novick
description: Sarah Krinsky and Daniel Novick are to be married May 21 at the Skirball Cultural Center in Los Angeles. Rabbi Rachel Ain, a friend of the couple, is to officiate.

title: Hadley Hosea, Peter Michalowski
description: Hadley Elizabeth Hosea and Peter Philip Michalowski were married May 20 in Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. James L. Francek, an affiliate of Citi Ministries, officiated at Wee Burn Country Club.

title: Sarah Ferguson, Rajan Banerjee
description: Sarah Christine Ferguson and Rajan Elliott Banerjee were married May 20 at Onteora Mountain House in Boiceville, N.Y. James E. LaFave, an uncle of the bride who is a Universal Life minister, officiated. Earlier in the day, Pandit Manojkumar Panigrahi led the couple in a traditional Hindu ceremony, also at the bed-and-breakfast.

title: Joseph Leggio, John Howells III
description: Joseph Frank Leggio and John Robert Howells III were married May 20 at the Diamond Horseshoe, an event space in Manhattan. Kevin J. McCarthy, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Sloane Smith, Jemel Saunders
description: Sloane Camille Smith, the daughter of Dr. Camille Baptiste-Smith and Dr. Clarence E. Smith of Miami Beach, was married May 20 to Jemel Lee Saunders, the son of Brenda J. Gomillion of Baldwin, N.Y., and Robbie L. Saunders of Henrico, Va. The Very Rev. Douglas McCaleb, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Miami.

title: Jennifer Cizner, Jeffrey Amsel
description: Jennifer Cheryl Cizner and Jeffrey Alan Amsel were married May 20. Rabbi Michael S. Siegel officiated at the Womans Athletic Club in Chicago.

title: Heather Phillips, Benjamin Silverman
description: Heather Michele Phillips and Benjamin William Silverman were married May 20 at Diviera Drive, a restaurant in Brooklyn. Perrin Wolfe, a friend of the couple and a minister with American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

title: Mets Bullpen Holds On to Beat the Angels
description: It was a night of milestones for the Mets  Terry Collinss 1,013th game as their manager, the most in team history, and Jose Reyes 2,000th hit  but until the very last pitch, a fastball from Addison Reed that pinch-hitter Danny Espinosa swung through with the bases loaded to secure a 7-5 victory, there was no guarantee of a reason to celebrate.

title: Kellene Eagen, Brian Schneirow
description: Dr. Kellene Vokaty Eagen and Brian Richard Schneirow were married May 20 at the Log Cabin in the Presidio park in San Francisco. Kathleen H. Eagen, the brides sister, was ordained through American Marriage Ministries to officiate.

title: Ayesha Choudhury, George Gonzalez
description: Ayesha Choudhury and George Arthur Gonzalez were married May 20 at the Montclair Art Museum in Montclair, N.J. Jamal Mahmood, a member of Muslims for Progressive Values performed a Muslim ceremony.

title: Caroline New, Michael Cappon
description: Caroline Ann New and Michael John Cappon were married May 20 at Bowmans Hill Wildflower Preserve in New Hope, Pa. Richard A. Cataldi, a friend of the couple who was ordained through American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

title: Emily Garber, Federico Pastorino
description: Emily Joan Garber and Dr. Federico Pastorino were married May 20. Wendy A. Curran, a justice of the peace in Ridgefield, Conn., officiated there at Lounsbury House.

title: Warriors Take 3-0 Series Lead on the Depleted Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO  Gregg Popovich, the coach of the San Antonio Spurs, had concocted a plan to combat the Golden State Warriors on Saturday night.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: Twin Peaks and Dark Angel
description: Twin Peaks returns, and what it brings with it is perhaps the biggest mystery of all. And Joanne Froggatt  thats Anna Bates of Downton Abbey to you  taps into her sinister side.

title: On Saturday Night Live, Alec Baldwin Sings a Swan Song for Trump
description: It was a night of milestones on Saturday Night Live, which in the final episode of its 42nd season, said goodbye to the longtime cast members Bobby Moynihan (who is joining the CBS sitcom Me, Myself & I) and Vanessa Bayer (who confirmed her departure in a bittersweet Instagram post).

title: Writers From the Right and Left React to This Weeks Trump News
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $900,000
description: 86 Irma Avenue, Port Washington

title: North Korea Fires Medium-Range Ballistic Missile
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea fired a missile on Sunday, a week after its successful test of a new intermediate-range ballistic missile, South Korean officials said.

title: Taliban Launch Rocket Attack and Kill at Least 20 Afghan Police Officers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a two-pronged attack in a southern Afghan province, the Taliban shelled the provincial capital city with rockets and then raided police outposts in a neighboring district, killing at least 20 officers and wounding six others, officials said on Sunday.

title: Trump Softens Tone on Islam but Calls for Purge of Foot Soldiers of Evil
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  President Trump on Sunday pivoted away from his strident assessment of Islam as a religion of hatred as he sought to redefine American leadership in the Middle East and rally the Muslim world to join him in a renewed campaign against extremism.

title: The Hardest Job in Politics: Presidential Spokesman
description: Ever since inauguration, the White House has struggled to keep its story straight  and now, communications director Michael Dubke has resigned. Conflicting messages, and President Trump himself, have made it difficult for the communications team to speak on his behalf.

title: Russia, Comey, Trump: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Over 60 and Dancing at W.N.B.A. Center Court
description: The Timeless Torches, a dance squad for the W.N.B.A.s Liberty, lets those over 40  many in their 60s  shake their booty on center court, breaking the tradition of the typical halftime act.

title: To Whom It Should Concern
description: This is the latest edition of the Race/Related newsletter. To get it in your inbox weekly,sign up here. Tell your friends andshare your stories.

title: 24 Hours of Music, Yoga and Art
description: Spend a day in Arcosanti, Ariz., where the FORM Festival curates more than just the musicians. Attendees must fill out an application to attend the three-day event, which includes meditative mornings and performance art pieces.

title: A Guide to Staying on Top of Your Student Loan
description: Good advice about student loans can be hard to find: Repayment options can be overwhelming, colleges dont provide great counseling and loan collectors can be bad actors. Thats why The New York Times has collected some of the best tips, tools and guides for families and students trying to figure out student debt.

title: President Trump Speaks to Muslim Leaders In Renewed Campaign Against Extremism
description: In a centerpiece speech in Riyadh, President Trump addressed leaders from around the Muslim world.

title: Democracy, It Turns Out, Suits the Warriors Just Fine
description: SAN ANTONIO  It sounds silly at this point, with the Golden State Warriors on the cusp of a third straight trip to the N.B.A. finals, to suggest that they faced challenges at the start of the season.

title: Cloud Computings Trainer Wins One for His Mentor at Preakness
description: BALTIMORE  You dont choose your mentors, they choose you. Ask Chad Brown. He was a small-town kid from upstate New York when the trainer Bobby Frankel decided to teach him what he knew.

title: Off to Italy to Study Painting: A Former Inmates Journey
description: JERSEY CITY  This is my paint gear, George Anthony Morton said, apologizing for splatters that only he could see on his black T-shirt. He had spent the afternoon at his easel, painting a portrait of someone he had asked to pose for him.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Democrats in New Jersey Governors Race Court Progressive Vote
description: NEWARK  With the heart of his campaign platform coming under repeated attack from Democratic opponents, Philip D. Murphy tried to claim a potent ally.

title: Erdogan Says He Will Extend His Sweeping Rule Over Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  In a signal that Turkey faces indefinite rule by decree, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced on Sunday that a state of emergency, introduced as a temporary measure after last years failed coup, would continue until the country achieved welfare and peace.

title: Get Me Rewrite! Now Its Late-Night Hosts Keeping Up With News
description: Around 5 p.m. last Monday, Steve Bodow, an executive producer at The Daily Show With Trevor Noah, was making final tweaks on that nights script when he saw a breaking news alert from The Washington Post: President Trump had disclosed classified intelligence to Russian officials in a White House meeting.

title: Afghan Magazine, a Sisterhood of Ideas, Hopes to Counter Mens Sway
description: The first issue of the Afghan womens magazine covers standard ground, like fashion tips during pregnancy and interviews with young pop artists about their love lives.

title: 19 and Coming Into His Own, Until a Fatal Night of Hazing
description: READINGTON, N.J.  Timothy Piazza started out a shy high school student in New Jersey who flushed so deeply scarlet when speaking to a girl that some called him Barney after the purple dinosaur. A growth spurt turned him into a gentle giant, keen to protect more vulnerable peers. He fell in love, became gregarious.

title: Three Climbers, One American, Die on Mount Everest
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Three climbers  one from Alabama, one from Slovakia and the third an Australian  died Sunday on Mount Everest, the worlds highest peak, and an Indian man disappeared while descending, officials and expedition leaders said.

title: Emboldened by Rouhanis Win, Iranians Seek Further Reforms
description: TEHRAN  Iranians came out in force to dance in the streets this weekend, breaking Islamic rules, to celebrate the re-election  of President Hassan Rouhani by a large margin.

title: Alien: Covenant Is a Ho-Hum No. 1 at the Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  Meh. The eighth chapter in 20th Century Foxs Alien series arrived to an estimated $36 million in ticket sales in North America  far from a flop, far from a sizzling hit. Alien: Covenant, as the latest film is titled, cost roughly $100 million to make, and has taken in an additional $30.3 million overseas.

title: Novak Djokovic Picks Andre Agassi to Be His Coach at the French Open
description: ROME  Andre Agassi will be Novak Djokovics coach at the French Open, Djokovic announced on Sunday.

title: Trump in Saudi Arabia
description: President Trump spoke about a renewed effort to stamp out extremism during a centerpiece speech to Muslim leaders in Saudi Arabia on Sunday.

title: This Wasnt a Speech About Islam
description: Two of our opinion writers, Mustafa Akyol in Istanbul and Wajahat Ali in the Washington, D.C. area, watched President Trumps speech in Saudi Arabia this morning and discussed what they thought it meant for the Middle East, American foreign policy and Muslims around the world.

title: A New Look at the Top of Womens Tennis: Its Wide Open
description: ROME  Asked Sunday if she believed, as the oddsmakers do, that she is the French Open favorite, Simona Halep dissented.

title: Networks Offer Taste of TVs Ad Future. Marketers Are Hungry for More.
description: Americas biggest television networks invited advertisers to New York institutions like Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center last week, giving them an early glimpse at their fall lineups and treating them to lavish parties and a parade of stars including Stephen Colbert, Kim Kardashian and Tony Romo, all with the aim of attracting billions of dollars in advertising by the end of the summer.

title: Republicans Watch Their Step in a Slow Retreat From Trump
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans on Sunday inched away from President Trump amid mounting evidence that he may have sought to interfere in the federal investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

title: No, Googles Not a Bird: Bringing the Internet to Rural India
description: TARADAND, India  Babulal Singh Neti was sitting with his uncle on a recent afternoon, trying to persuade him of the merits of the internet.

title: White House, Saudi Arabia, North Korea: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Pittsburgh Welcomed Ubers Driverless Car Experiment. Not Anymore.
description: PITTSBURGH  When Uber picked this former Rust Belt town as the inaugural city for its driverless car experiment, Pittsburgh played the consummate host.

title: Notre Dame Students Walk Out of Mike Pence Commencement Address
description: A large crowd of students walked out of the Notre Dame commencement ceremony on Sunday in protest of the speaker, Vice President Mike Pence, who delivered a speech that mixed platitudes about bright, dream-filled futures with a lengthy rebuke of political correctness on college campuses.

title: Tom Hardy to Star in Venom
description: He played a formidable villain for DC Comics, and now hell do the same for Marvel: Tom Hardy has signed on to lead Venom, a spinoff movie in Marvels expanding universe.

title: A Black Actor in Virginia Woolf? Not Happening, Albee Estate Says
description: A decision by the estate of Edward Albee not to allow a production of Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? to cast a black actor as a blond character is reigniting decades-long debates in the theater world over race, casting and authorial control.

title: Wind Project in Wyoming Envisions Coal Miners as Trainees
description: Goldwind Americas, an arm of a leading wind-turbine manufacturer based in China, has been expanding its business in the United States. It has been careful to seek out local, American workers for permanent jobs on the wind farms it supplies.

title: Review: Future and Migos, Onstage With Their Hits on Shuffle
description: In January, the Atlanta trio Migos ascended to the top of the Billboard Hot 100 with Bad and Boujee, one of their signature choppy anthems, bolstered by meme-friendly opening lyrics. The next month, the Atlanta elder Future pulled off something no artist ever had: debuting atop the Billboard album chart in two consecutive weeks with two different albums, Future followed by Hndrxx.

title: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Andrea Petersen on Living With, and Studying, Anxiety
description: Toward the end of 1989, Andrea Petersen, then a sophomore at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, was transformed from a slightly silly sorority girl to a terrorized shut-in in just a few weeks time. Thats how she describes the onset of panic attacks and their confusing aftermath in On Edge, her new memoir about having what was eventually diagnosed as several forms of anxiety. The book also looks back at the history of our understanding of the various disorders under the umbrella of anxiety, and surveys the latest attempts to combat them. Below, Petersen, a contributing writer at The Wall Street Journal, tells how she overcame worries about disclosing her experiences, whats changed (and what hasnt) in treatment, and more.

title: A Bachelorette Bible
description: There is a mantra often repeated on The Bachelor and its spinoff, The Bachelorette: Here for the right reasons. Contestants who go on the show to put their trust in the process, find true love and settle down are here for the right reasons. Those who come to take off their tops, boost their Instagram followings and land hosting gigs on the spring break party circuit are not.

title: Pippa Middletons Wedding Dress: What Is the Story?
description: When does an ostensibly private family event become fair game for media attention? This perennial question for the global press  and its readership  was raised once again this past weekend, when Pippa Middleton, younger sister to Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, married James Matthews in Berkshire, England.

title: Profiles of Six Candidates for New Jersey Governor

title: Aaron Judge, His Bat Dulled, Makes Brilliant Catch in Yankees Win
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  When the Yankees Aaron Judge takes his place on a baseball field, he cuts a larger-than-life figure. He stands 6 feet 7 inches, weighs 275 pounds and is so rock solid that when he ran into a wall at Fenway Park recently, Manager Joe Girardi said he was concerned for the wall.

title: Mets Take a Beating From the Angels as Tommy Milone Falters
description: Throughout the weekend, Mets Manager Terry Collins spoke reverently of Angels outfielder Mike Trout, perhaps the most feared hitter in baseball.

title: Review: Squeezing Music Made for One Hall Into the Geffen
description: The end of the New York Philharmonics season is near and with it the close of Alan Gilberts tenure as music director. With his final appearances at Lincoln Center, he seems to be working through items on a bucket list, among them performances of a full Wagner opera (Das Rheingold, starting June 1) and a political statement in the form of concerts (beginning June 7) featuring musicians from Iran, Iraq and Israel, among other countries. On Friday Mr. Gilbert fulfilled another wish: to finally bring to David Geffen Hall the mating call of the male plainfin midshipman.

title: Why Send Germany a Statue of Marx? The Chinese Have Some Ideas
description: BEIJING  From China, with love. Or something more insidious?

title: It Was Hard This Year to Keep Politics Out of High School Yearbooks
description: A high school yearbook is a keepsake. Like an Instagram filter, its meant to bathe recent memories in the warm, soft-focus glow of nostalgia. As an object, it evokes affection and community; you hope to show it to your children and grandchildren someday. A yearbook isnt supposed to be divisive.

title: Bringing the Dream of an Elite College to Rural Students
description: SAMPSON COUNTY, N.C.  The first time Nyreke Peters met the new college adviser at his rural high school, he was skeptical. Other adults at Hobbton High School spoke with the same Southern accent and shared an easygoing familiarity that came from having gone to the same schools and having spent their lives in the same county.

title: In Wreckage of the Fyre Festival, Fury, Lawsuits and an Inquiry
description: A few days after the spectacular collapse of the Fyre Festival, just as federal investigators began to circle the wreckage, the events would-be mastermind, Billy McFarland, was still making promises.

title: Lack of Workers, Not Work, Weighs on the Nations Economy
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Stephanie Pappas and her brothers built their roofing supply company in this fast-growing region by promising next-day delivery, but lately theyve been forced to tell some customers that tomorrow is impossible.

title: Liverpool Chases Away Butterflies to Earn a Champions League Berth
description: LIVERPOOL, England  Only when the second goal came could the home crowd at Anfield finally, guardedly allow itself to breathe. The atmosphere had been taut until that moment, close to an hour into Sundays match  Liverpools Premier League finale against Middlesbrough.

title: In Comeback, Pedro Snchez Is Re-elected Leader of Spanish Socialists
description: MADRID  The ousted leader of Spains main opposition Socialist Party, Pedro Snchez, made a remarkable comeback on Sunday, winning re-election as party leader only seven months after stepping down in defeat.

title: Roxcy Bolton, Feminist Crusader for Equality, Including in Naming Hurricanes, Dies at 90
description: Roxcy Bolton, a pioneering and tempestuous Florida feminist who was credited with founding the nations first rape treatment center and who helped persuade national weather forecasters not to name tropical storms after only women, died on May 17 in Coral Gables, Fla. She was 90.

description: Hospitals around the country are scrambling to stockpile vials of a critical drug  even postponing operations or putting off chemotherapy treatments  because the countrys only two suppliers have run out.

description: Saying conditions at Pennsylvania Station in New York have reached a crisis, and that planned track closings would lead to a summer of agony, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo appealed to President Trump on Sunday to recognize the situation as an emergency and provide funding for construction and transportation alternatives for commuters.

title: Preparations for Trumps Visit Expose Political Rifts in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Unlike the royal pomp and ceremony with which President Trump was greeted over the weekend in Saudi Arabia, the plans for his arrival on Monday in Israel had devolved into an unseemly political ruckus before Air Force One touched down.

description: See what Vanessa Hudgens, Halsey, John Legend and more wore to the show in Las Vegas.

title: In Saudi Arabia, Trump Reaches Out to Sunni Nations, at Irans Expense

title: Ivanka Trump Swayed the President on Family Leave. Congress Is a Tougher Sell.
description: Ivanka Trump has largely cast herself as a behind-the-scenes force for moderation in the West Wing, but this week she will take her first real political risk when her signature parental leave plan is presented to a conservative House majority hostile to any new government mandates.

title: After 146 Years, Ringling Brothers Circus Takes Its Final Bow
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The lights went up on the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus on Sunday evening to reveal 14 lions and tigers sitting in a circle, surrounding a man in a sparkling suit. It was a sight too implausible to seem real yet such an iconic piece of Americana that it was impossible to believe the show would not go on.

title: After Fleeing Bias at Home, Gay Russians Say It Persists in Brooklyn
description: For many years, Denis Kruglenko treated life as if it were a delicately calibrated performance. A gay man living in Belgorod, Russia, he knew that even appearing to be homosexual could be perilous. He did what he could to conceal his sexual orientation but it never seemed to be enough. Once, he was beaten up for wearing a pair of pink socks.

title: Quotation of the Day: Shifting Tone, President Saves Dark Words for a Faiths Fringe
description: Love your shoes. Boy, those shoes. Man!

title: Apple Pay Violates Patents Held by Security Technology Inventor, Lawsuit Alleges
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A small Boston company, founded by the inventor of a popular corporate encryption technology called RSA SecurID, sued Apple and Visa on Sunday, arguing that the Apple Pay digital payment technology violates its patents.

title: Caught in White House Chaos, Justice Dept. Official Seeks Neutral Ground
description: WASHINGTON  Last month, Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general at the center of the crisis building around President Trumps White House, gathered with federal prosecutors and law enforcement officials to bid farewell to his old job, United States attorney in Maryland, and celebrate his new one.

title: The Leftovers Season 3, Episode 6 Recap: The End Is Near
description: After this weeks episode of The Leftovers, there are only two hours of TV time  give or take a few minutes  for creators Damon Lindelof and Tom Perrotta to reach some kind of resolution. But for a show so steeped in the eternal mysteries of faith, doubt and spiritual fulfillment, what does a resolution even look like?

title: Review: The Whirligig Is a Feast for Actors, by a Knowing Chef
description: Hamish Linklater, the author of the new play The Whirligig, is best known as an actor. And for the overstuffed drama that opened on Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center, he has whipped up a multicourse meal for fellow actors to feast upon.

title: The Censors Disappearing Vibrator
description: SINGAPORE  Nobody told me that the format of The Ellen DeGeneres Show had changed, so imagine my surprise one recent afternoon when the credits appeared after only 30 minutes of dancing and funny videos. I discovered later that the second half of this episode featured two segments with celebrity guests that did not survive the Singapore censors scrutiny: Jane Fonda wielding a vibrator and Asia Kate Dillon discussing her nonbinary gender identity, both considered too taboo for daytime television here.

title: Review: In Twin Peaks, an Old Log Learns Some New Tricks
description: One of the creepiest images in the new Twin Peaks is a glass box, ensconced in a window in New York City, which is kept under constant observation in case something comes through it. (Not-such-a-spoiler alert: Something does.)

title: Word + Quiz: aseptic
From Hockey 101 to a Ph.D. in Nashville
description: NASHVILLE  In the beginning, before the Nashville Predators sank their fangs into a city that adored hockey but just didnt know it yet, there was a kiosk. Nat Harden perched there, outside the food court of the CoolSprings mall in suburban Brentwood, eight hours a day, five days a week during the 1997 holiday season and tried to sell a sport that he had never seen in person and a team that had no players.

title: Museum of the Future: Portable and Personal
description: Dayanita Singh has spent the past decade creating customizable photo books that are a portable exhibit and catalog in one.

title: Donald Trump, Our A.I. President
description: It is hard to imagine a more scathing indictment of our ability to read anothers thoughts and intentions than our inability to predict Donald Trumps next move. From the gross pre-election misjudgments to postelection bafflement, the best pundits are at a loss to accurately anticipate his response to matters like North Korean military aggressiveness or his moment-by-moment political gyrations and opinion reversals. Labeling Trump a narcissist, psychopath, megalomaniac or attention-impaired, or all of the above, might feel explanatory, but even when armed with the best psychoanalytic insights, we have no idea what he will do when presented with a new or unforeseen circumstance.

title: Lurching Backward on Justice Reform
description: When it comes to criminal justice, Attorney General Jeff Sessions is a man out of time  stuck defiantly in the 1980s, when crime in America was high and politicians scrambled to out-tough one another by passing breathtakingly severe sentencing laws. This mind-set was bad enough when Mr. Sessions was a senator from Alabama working to thwart sentencing reforms in Congress. Now that he is the nations top law enforcement officer, hes trying to drag the country backward with him, even as most states are moving toward more enlightened policies.

title: China and India Make Big Strides on Climate Change
description: Until recently, China and India have been cast as obstacles, at the very least reluctant conscripts, in the battle against climate change. That reputation looks very much out-of-date now that both countries have greatly accelerated their investments in cost-effective renewable energy sources  and reduced their reliance on fossil fuels. Its America  Donald Trumps America  that now looks like the laggard.

title: How the Swastika Became a Confederate Flag
description: The easy-listening white supremacists who surged out of the shadows during the presidential campaign are no less dangerous than their white power survivalist or raving skinhead counterparts. But they are hoping to rebrand themselves by wearing business clothes and attempting to sound reasonable as they advance a racist agenda. The debate about removing monuments to white supremacy that were built throughout the South a century or more ago is tailor-made for this tactic.

title: Tired of New Yorks Subways? Blame Andrew Cuomo
description: When the Metropolitan Transportation Authority opened the Second Avenue Subway extension in January, Gov. Andrew Cuomo was quick to put his stamp on the new line. At news conferences, inaugural rides and even a star-studded New Years Eve party, the governor branded the project as his own.

title: Blood in the Water
description: Donald Trump has left the country for his first foreign trip as president and what he has left behind is a brewing crisis that appears to deepen by the day, and even the hour.

title: The Order of Lenin: Find Some Truly Hard People

He was talking about the first director of the Marx-Engels Institute, founded in 1919: An old Bolshevik, David Riazanov had little patience for the Communist Party officials who constantly demanded documents either to confirm ideological positions or to blacken enemies.

description: LONDON  The Huntsman Corporation said on Monday that it had agreed to merge with Clariant of Switzerland, continuing a consolidation push in the chemicals industry.

description: THE WITCHFINDERS SISTER By Beth Underdown 312 pp. Ballantine Books. $28

title: 50 Years On, Stories of the Six Day War and What Came After
description: What new insight can a bunch of Very Important Writers provide about the Israeli occupation of the West Bank? Phrased a little differently  Michael Chabon and Ayelet Waldman call these novelists and essayists storytellers  this is the question the two editors of KINGDOM OF OLIVES AND ASH: Writers Confront the Occupation (Harper Perennial, paper, $16.99) decided to pose on the occupations 50th anniversary. (Moriel Rothman-Zecher was associate editor.) They gathered their friends, most of whom, they admit, had never given the occupation more than a glancing consideration, and took them on weeklong tours of East Jerusalem, the village of Susiya in the south Hebron hills and the cities of Hebron and Ramallah, all flash points where Israeli control over Palestinian lives can be felt acutely. The result is an exhausting collection of essays. And with a few strong exceptions  like the pieces by Dave Eggers, Rachel Kushner and Waldman herself  they are what you might expect: fairly superficial, full of unearned authority and exhibitionist empathy. A parachute job.

title: White House Moves to Block Ethics Inquiry Into Ex-Lobbyists on Payroll
description: The Trump administration, in a significant escalation of its clash with the governments top ethics watchdog, has moved to block an effort to disclose the names of former lobbyists who have been granted waivers to work in the White House or federal agencies.

title: Bill Cosby Trial: Five Jurors Are Chosen in a Painstaking Process
description: PITTSBURGH  Sorting through a jury pool already exposed to the blaze of publicity over allegations against Bill Cosby, lawyers and a judge on Monday selected the first five jurors, all of them white, who will weigh whether he committed a sexual assault.

title: Alone on the Open Road: Truckers Feel Like Throwaway People
description: EFFINGHAM, Ill.  The vast Petro truck stop here is a neon-lit, blacktop oasis at the crossroads of America. It beckons big-rig drivers with showers, laundry machines, a barber shop, even a knife store. Professional drivers only, reads the sign above the tables of the Iron Skillet restaurant, where truckers sit mostly alone, carrying the solitude of their jobs into an otherwise social setting.

title: Movie Ticket Sales Sagging? Time to Bring Out the Toys
description: BURBANK, Calif.  The once-catatonic corner of moviedom dedicated to merchandise has suddenly come alive as studios  walloped by vanishing DVD sales and determined to keep fans engaged between sequels  look at themed toys, clothes and home dcor with renewed vigor.

title: Brand to Know: The Line That Focuses Only on Shirting
description: You know, when you do a mono-product line, you need to feel inspired by it, says Aude Castja, the French designer behind the young brand Monographie. Her line is mono in that every garment is a riff on the same concept: shirting. In some cases, she has cut fabric away at the shoulders, while other pieces feature a bib front, an off-center opening or a series of cuffs stacked surreally up the sleeve. There are so many options, she says of the shirts possibilities. I feel its endless.

Then it rode economic recovery and cheap gasoline to record sales and profits. But what looks like success can turn upside down quickly in Detroit these days.

title: Drilling for a Dream in Myanmar
description: NGA NAUNG MONE, Myanmar  Soon after dawn, Win Myint Oo, bleary-eyed and wearing just a longyi, a traditional Burmese sarong, starts a generator and squats on a bamboo platform suspended under a 40-foot, jury-rigged derrick: just three steel poles and bamboo struts lashed together with rope.

title: Nearly 20 Million Have Gained Health Insurance Since 2010
description: The number of Americans without health insurance has fallen drastically in recent years, according to new data from the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: Celtics Upset of Cavaliers Stretches Out a Foregone Conclusion
description: So the Boston Celtics beat the Cavaliers, in Cleveland, on Sunday night despite being 16-point underdogs. And they did it in their first game without their star, Isaiah Thomas, who is out for the season with a hip injury.

title: Some Social Scientists Are Tired of Asking for Permission
description: If you took Psychology 101 in college, you probably had to enroll in an experiment to fulfill a course requirement or to get extra credit.
