description: They are kept behind the counter at the 7-Eleven store on the Upper East Side, out of reach and available only by request, like cigarettes and lottery tickets and chewing tobacco. So close, yet so far from the restless fingers that crave them the most.

title: Justices Reject 2 Gerrymandered North Carolina Districts, Citing Racial Bias
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court struck down two North Carolina congressional districts on Monday, ruling that lawmakers had violated the Constitution by relying too heavily on race in drawing them, in a decision that could affect many voting maps, generally in the South.

title: Citigroup Agrees to $97.4 Million Settlement in Money Laundering Inquiry
description: For years, Citigroup employees feared that millions of dollars the bank was moving to Mexico might be suspicious. Yet in many cases, the bank did not alert regulators or step up its monitoring for money laundering, federal prosecutors said Monday.

title: Irans President Mocks Trumps Saudi Arabia Trip as Just a Show
description: TEHRAN  Flush from his decisive re-election victory, Irans president struck back on Monday after a weekend of verbal affronts from the Saudi-American summit meeting, describing President Trumps visit to Riyadh as empty theatrics and mocking his support for a monarchy that has never seen a ballot box.

title: Joel Meyerowitz: Towards Colour 1962-1978
description: A new show in London explores a pioneer of color photography  and the vivid images he produced.

title: The 60s Photographer Who Captured the Street in Vivid Color
description: In 1962, Joel Meyerowitz left his job in advertising and set out to be a photographer. He started by venturing outside with two Leica cameras (one loaded with color film and the other with black and white) to snap the world in motion: In one image, a man strides through the streets of New York cradling an enormous dog in his arms; in another, a couple zooms through Greece on a scooter, the womans scarf blurred by the wind.

title: A New Book Celebrates Americas Brunch Drink
description: Nothing is easier than a Bloody Mary: Open a can of tomato-based mix, add vodka and garnish with a celery stick. It is about the only drink for which I would use a premixed base, and in a pinch I have been known to start with diluted ketchup. In this new book, youll find a guide to assembling the classic Bloody Mary and the freedom to experiment with variations like a Korean version seasoned with kimchi pure, a garden-fresh take with muddled cherry tomatoes, or a tomato water martini. The drinks history and bar snacks are included. The broiled Parmesan-shallot toasts deserve to be added to the repertoire: The Bloody Mary Book by Ellen Brown (Running Press, $18).

title: What Was That Glowing Orb Trump Touched in Saudi Arabia?
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  A mysterious glowing orb is exerting uncanny power over the worlds social media.

title: Snacks From an East Village Wine Bar Available Online
description: At Lois, a tap-only wine bar in the East Village, customers can nibble snacks like candied pepitas with a glass of white. Popular demand has inspired the owners, Nora OMalley and Phoebe Connell, to produce and sell their crisps, crackers and candied nuts to a wider world. Candied Sichuan pecans with a veneer of spice, dusky rye crackers, and sourdough crackers that beg for cheese are particularly addictive: Aida Pantry Staples, $8 to $10 each, all five for $46, aidaeats.com.

title: Celebrating Carmelita Maracci, Who Took the Girdle Off Ballet
description: Pulling off as many as 13 perfect pirouettes on pointe is astonishingly hard, but was simply a matter of course for Carmelita Maracci. Still, the day she did 17, students in the ballet class she was teaching in Los Angeles hoisted her aloft and ran triumphantly down Hollywood Boulevard. Or so the story goes.

title: What Critics Are Saying About the New Twin Peaks
description: In the weeks leading up to Showtimes anxiously awaited Twin Peaks: The Return, critics seized the opportunity to spend time with David Lynchs original series, recapping and reappraising and recounting the behind-the-scenes story of the game-changing mystery that premiered on ABC in 1990. The one thing they couldnt do was review the new series  because, in true Lynchian fashion, no advance screeners were distributed to the media. (On Friday, there was an embargoed premiere screening in Los Angeles.)

title: 629,000 Overstayed U.S. Visas Last Year, Homeland Security Says
description: WASHINGTON  An estimated 629,000 visitors to the United States  just over 1 percent of all travelers  remained in the country at the end of last year after overstaying their visas as students, workers or tourists, according to a report released on Monday by the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Creamy, Dreamy Sorbet Sandwiches for Hot Summer Nights
description: For a warm-weather treat, the pastry chef Marc Aumont is now making macaron sorbet sandwiches at the sweets shop next door to Gabriel Kreuthers restaurant. Cheesecake sorbet is a name that doesnt quite do justice to the delectable frozen confection at the center of these crisp, feather-light cookie sandwiches. A subtle tang from the Philadelphia cream cheese used in the sorbet comes through in the plain version, but less so with the berry or pistachio. The chocolate filling is his dark chocolate sorbet, no cheese: Frozen Macaron Sandwiches, $6.50, Kreuther Handcrafted Chocolate, 43 West 42nd Street, 212-201-1985, kreutherchocolate.com.

title: How to Make It Known Theres a Problem With an App
description: Q. Is there any way to report problems or get technical support for a mobile app?

title: Food Waste Is the Topic of Conversation at 92nd Street Y
description: The chef Mads Refslund and the professional forager Tama Matsuoka Wong will reveal techniques for putting discarded items like cabbage cores, potato skins and coffee grounds to tasty use during a talk at the 92nd Street Y, as they have done in their new book, Scraps, Wilt & Weeds: Turning Wasted Food Into Plenty. There will also be a book signing: Mads Refslund and Tama Matsuoka Wong, June 6, 7 p.m., 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (92nd Street), tickets $29, 212-415-5500, 92y.org.

title: Gadget Makes Peeling Eggs a Tad Easier
description: This clever plastic egg peeler really works. Place a hard-cooked egg in the container, add a little water, cover and shake up and down until the sound the egg makes diminishes. Then it will be a cinch to peel. Without the Connecticut-made gadget, invented by a home cook with too many deviled eggs to prepare, you could use a jelly jar with some water almost as effectively: The Negg, $17.99, neggmaker.com.

title: Daily Report: Cleaning Up the Internet
description: The internet has been a powerful engine for spreading information. It has also spread online harassment and fake news and fed other toxic digital behavior.

title: Harry Styles Becomes 2nd One Direction Member With a Solo No. 1
description: During its reign as the pre-eminent boy band of the 2010s, One Direction scored four No. 1 albums. Now two of its former members have also reached the top.

title: Who Is Sheriff Clarke of Milwaukee County? A Brief Guide
description: David A. Clarke Jr., the sheriff of Milwaukee County, was back in the news last week after announcing that he had been appointed to the Department of Homeland Security. (The Trump administration itself has not confirmed the appointment.)

title: Trump Seeks Delay of Ruling on Health Law Subsidies, Prolonging Uncertainty
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration asked a federal appeals court on Monday to delay ruling on a lawsuit that could determine whether the government will continue paying subsidies under the Affordable Care Act to health insurance companies for the benefit of low-income people  effectively prolonging uncertainty that is already rattling the health law.

title: VC One Hour Test Video
description: Summary

title: At Olmsted, a Living Memory of a Farm-to-Table Meal
description: For Greg Baxtrom, the chef and owner of Olmsted in Brooklyn, farm-to-table is as close as his restaurants backyard. There he raises herbs, radishes, asparagus and other produce. Mr. Baxtrom recently took over an adjacent plot, built a greenhouse and expanded his harvest with berries, carrots and sprouts. For a $10 fee, customers can dig up an herb or pepper plant and take it home in a special little crate. People can participate and take a memory away, Mr. Baxtrom said. Diners must also transplant a seedling from the greenhouse to the garden spot where they have removed their plant. Proceeds go to GrowNYC, the environmental organization that runs the citys Greenmarkets: Olmsted, 659 Vanderbilt Avenue (Park Place), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, 718-552-2610, olmstednyc.com.

title: Microblading, Tattoos, Extensions: The Answer to an Easier Morning
description: Despite the loud Instagram makeup trends that continue to rage, a lot of women are feeling a disconnect. They simply want to make it out the door feeling as if they are relatively put together. Because, lets be honest, who has the time?

title: St. Pauls School Acknowledges Decades of Sexual Misconduct
description: There was an English teacher, the investigators said, who groped a student and had a sexual relationship with another. A female student said a music teacher sexually touched her in his car. And there was a sacred studies teacher, a minister, whom one student accused of rape.

title: Jim Hackett, Fords New C.E.O., Has a History of Turnaround Stories
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Jim Hackett made his career by turning Steelcase, an office-furniture maker in Michigan, into one of Americas most admired companies. More recently, he rejuvenated one of the countrys most storied college athletic programs, at the University of Michigan, and hired its high-profile football coach, Jim Harbaugh.

title: Barnard Chooses a Leader Whose Research Focuses on Women
description: Barnard College announced on Monday that it had hired Sian Beilock to be its next president, the eighth person to hold the position.

title: A Taste for Poison in Warmer Climates?
description: Q. Why does venom seem to be more favored as a defense by animals in warmer latitudes?

title: Staffing Imbalances Reveal New York Jails Growing Pains
description: In a swirl of scandals and struggles to address violence on Rikers Island, Mayor Bill de Blasio has poured resources into New York Citys Correction Department, hoping to right the ship. More than 1,000 officers have been added during the mayors term, and the department has recorded a sharp rise in its civilian head count for oversight, new programs and overhauls.

title: Arconic Settles With Elliott After Bruising and Public Dispute
description: Arconic has grappled with a lot over the last year.

title: Knicks Will Not Renew Contract of Josh Longstaff, an Assistant Coach
description: The N.B.A. is a league built, in part, on the work of assistant coaches, some with shiny names from their playing careers and some who remain anonymous, doing most of their work in the shadows. Josh Longstaff was one such assistant, a member of the Knicks coaching staff for the past three seasons who focused on player development.

title: U.S. Nuclear History Offers Clues to North Koreas Progress
description: It started with Einstein. His famous E = mc2 revealed a vast asymmetry in the cosmic relationship between matter and energy. In time, experts looked into the possibility of exploiting the disparity.

title: VC Trim Video Test
description: summary

title: We All Remember the World Series Celebration. How About the Guy Who Made the Last Out?
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The boyhood dream was so vivid that Michael Martinez can still remember it in rich detail: how he stood at the left side of the plate and delivered the winning hit in the seventh game of the World Series for the Cleveland Indians.

title: Ford Was Unprepared for Investor Revolt and C.E.O. Change
description: Ford Motors many gaffes under Mark Fields were becoming an existential crisis for the $43 billion carmakers founding family. Two weeks ago, a majority of those shareholders not named Ford voted to abolish the familys super-voting stock. The Fords got the message, and Mr. Fields, the chief executive, is now leaving. But naming a 62-year-old from the furniture trade to replace him hints at how unprepared the family was for a revolt.

title: Review: Liam Scarletts Symphonic Dances Celebrates a Ballerina
description: LONDON  A vast, cavernous space, dominated by a smoky cone of light. Thats the first image of Liam Scarletts new Symphonic Dances, an ambitious, large-scale work for the Royal Ballet that opened at the Royal Opera House here on May 18 and continues through Wednesday, sharing a program with William Forsythes The Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude, Balanchines Tarantella and Christopher Wheeldons Strapless.

title: Italienne
description: The chef Jared Sippels first New York restaurant is on its way to being something out of the ordinary.

title: An Identity Crisis at Italienne
description: Jared Sippel might have had too much time to think before he opened Italienne. The restaurant, the chefs first in New York City, has been open since the fall and is on its way to being something well out of the ordinary. But Mr. Sippel is trying to do so many things at once that his point of view gets garbled. The potential for confusion is even embedded in the name, which means Italian in French.

title: N.B.A. Player Enes Kanter Blames Erdogan for Detention in Romania
description: Enes Kanter, the Turkish N.B.A. player who was detained in Romania over the weekend, spoke out against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Monday in New York and filled in some of the details of his odyssey.

title: A New Reader Service: Ask the Sketch Guy Anything
description: I want to try something Im calling Ask the Sketch Guy.

title: Turkey Chides U.S. Envoy Over Handling of Brawl at Washington Protest
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish Foreign Ministry summoned the American ambassador in Ankara on Monday to complain about the detention of two Turkish security officers outside the Turkish Embassy in Washington last week, a Turkish official said.

title: Supreme Court Ruling Could Hinder Patent Trolls
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday placed tight limits on where patent lawsuits may be filed  a unanimous decision that was a blow to so-called patent trolls, or companies that buy patents not to use them but to demand royalties and sue for damages.

title: Lawyers Are the Big Winners in the Inquiry Into the Election
description: The appointment of Robert S. Mueller III as special counsel to oversee the Justice Departments investigation of possible Russian involvement in the 2016 election means that White House staff members and others connected to President Trumps presidential campaign will need to do one thing quickly: Lawyer up.

title: The Census and Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: U.K. Conservatives Retreat After Backlash Over Dementia Tax
description: LONDON  Having called an early election in an attempt to expand her partys majority in Parliament, Prime Minister Theresa May is pitching her strong and stable leadership at a time when Britain confronts the formidable challenge of leaving the European Union.

title: Review: Before Pooh Bear, There Was Milnes The Lucky One
description: Did someone declare this the Year to Dust Off Seldom Performed Plays About Feuding Brothers? First there was the Broadway revival of The Price, Arthur Millers 1968 drama, which closed on May 14. And now comes The Lucky One, the Mint Theaters remounting of an A .A. Milne play written almost a century ago and given a brief run on Broadway in 1922.

title: Big Game Hunter Killed by Elephant in Zimbabwe
description: A South African big game hunter was killed in Zimbabwe on Friday when an elephant that had been shot by another hunter fell on him.

title: Trumps Message in Saudi Arabia
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharing Moroccan Shakshuka With Mourad Lahlou
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Shaved head glowing under the fluorescent kitchen lights, arms tattooed from shoulder to wrist, the chef Mourad Lahlou of Mourad restaurant waved a flower-patterned Japanese fan furiously over the countertop brazier, inciting the charcoal to glow.

title: Michael Flynn Misled Pentagon About Russia Ties, Letter Says
description: WASHINGTON  Michael T. Flynn, President Trumps former national security adviser, misled Pentagon investigators about his income from companies in Russia and contacts with officials there when he applied for a renewal of his top-secret security clearance last year, according to a letter released Monday by the top Democrat on the House oversight committee.

title: 59,000 Haitians Displaced by Earthquake Get Extra 6 Months in U.S.
description: MIAMI  More than seven years after an earthquake shattered Haitis capital, the secretary of Homeland Security, John F. Kelly, announced Monday that he would grant 58,700 Haitians another six months to live and work in the United States.

title: Alexei Ratmansky Plans a New (Old) Harlequinade for Ballet Theater
description: One of the 21st centurys greatest choreographers is taking another drink from the fount of classical ballet: Alexei Ratmansky plans to create a new Harlequinade next year for American Ballet Theater, a reconstruction of Marius Petipas ballet Les Millions dArlequin.

title: These Baby Mice Were Born From Sperm That Went to Space
description: Litters of healthy mice  space pups  prove that mouse sperm can be freeze-dried, flown around on the International Space Station for nine months and then used to make babies, researchers from Japan are reporting in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Join Digital News Design at The New York Times
description: We are seeking technology-savvy interactive designers/editors to join our award-winning team in The New York Times newsroom.

title: Interviewing Truck Drivers at a Crossroads
description: The sign said Professional Drivers Only, which was intimidating. At a truck stop in Effingham, Ill., gruff-looking figures wearing camo hats and hundred-mile stares sat at a counter of the Iron Skillet Restaurant.

title: Homeless in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Palliative Care Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Ray Joins Ancient and Contemporary in Sculpture Debut in Rome
description: ROME  Mention the name of the American artist Charles Ray, and Italy holds its breath. Mr. Ray made waves in the country in 2013 when his Boy with Frog, a hypernaturalistic, 8-foot-tall sculpture commissioned by Franois Pinault, the French luxury goods magnate and collector, was removed from the Punta della Dogana in Venice because of protests on the part of locals, who demanded the return of a displaced lamppost there, a favorite smooching spot.

title: Sending Addicts to Jail: Draconian and a Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Sea Lion Grabs a Girl Off a Dock, and Social Media Turns on Her Parents
description: Signs posted along the Steveston docks in Richmond, British Columbia, a popular tourist spot, do not mince words: Dont feed the sea lions, because a bite can cause very serious infections that may lead to amputation of a limb or even death.

title: Monica Lewinsky: Roger Ailess Dream Was My Nightmare
description: This is not another obituary for Roger Ailes, who died last week 10 months after being ousted at Fox News. It is, I hope, instead an obituary for the culture he purveyed  a culture that affected me profoundly and personally.

title: Billy Bush, Former Today Host, Plans Comeback After Lewd Trump Recording
description: Billy Bush, the former Today host whose lewd conversation with Donald J. Trump in 2005 roiled the presidential race, said in his first media interview since he left NBC in October that he spent his months away from the spotlight trying to become a better, fuller man.

title: Manchester, Israel, North Korea: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Fendis Gift to Rome: A Sculpture Shaped Like a Tree
description: PIETRASANTA, Italy  Shading his eyes from the warm Tuscan sun, the artist Giuseppe Penone watched as a crane hoisted a bronze tree trunk into position to cradle an 11-ton carved marble block.

title: After Report on Killings of C.I.A. Sources, China Asserts Right to Defend Itself
description: The Chinese government has the obligation to defend its national security and the legal authority to protect Chinas interests, a government spokeswoman said on Monday, the first official response to a New York Times report on the dismantling of C.I.A. espionage operations in China.

title: Abandoning Human Rights in U.S. Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Drink Up, Business Travelers. The Minibar Is on the Way Out.
description: Do you think of hotel rooms as having spacious, old-school desks, the kind that invite long hours of working? And bureaus with a half-dozen drawers? Minibars, too? Well, perhaps you havent stayed at a hotel lately.

title: Kenyas Struggling Uber Drivers Fear a New Competitor: Uber
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  James Njoroge, an Uber driver in Nairobi, earns barely $5 at the end of a grueling 10-hour workday ferrying customers through snarled traffic across the Kenyan capital. Now a new competitor is in town, threatening to undercut even these meager earnings.

title: A Global Health Scorecard Finds U.S. Lacking
description: Over the last 25 years, China, Ethiopia, the Maldive Islands, Peru, South Korea and Turkey had the greatest improvements in deaths avoidable through health care at their economic level, a complex but intriguing new measure of global mortality described last week in the Lancet.

title: Cummings Urges Chaffetz to Subpoena Flynn
description: In a letter to Representative Jason Chaffetz, the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, Representative Elijah E. Cummings, the ranking minority member, requested a subpoena for documents related to any connections between Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, and Russia. In the request, Mr. Cummings highlights an encounter between Mr. Flynn and high-level Russian officials that he failed to disclose for a security clearance check as reasoning for the subpoena.

title: At Moogfest, Untamed Sounds and Futuristic Protests
description: DURHAM, N.C.  On Thursday afternoon at Moogfest, electronic sounds whooshed and crashed and videos of waveforms flickered and rippled behind Camae Ayewa, a musician, producer, poet, rapper and community organizer based in Philadelphia who records as Moor Mother. From her nest of equipment, she layered tumultuous beats and brittle electronic loops, and she declaimed ideas about history, racism, memory, technology and transformation. Everyone is at home deleting the human parts of themselves/Control-Alt-Delete, she intoned.

title: A Hamlet Poised Between Cultures (and Languages)
description: As if the poor guy werent conflicted enough, Hamlet has taken on an extra burden of ambivalence in the new Waterwell production of the play that bears his name. In addition to worrying about all the usual melancholy Dane stuff  whether to be or not to be, act or not to act, help or hurt his mom  he is now torn (to pieces) between cultural identities.

title: Twin Peaks Season 3, Episodes 1-2: Back in Style
description: Part of what made the first season of Twin Peaks so popular back in 1990 was that it filtered the director David Lynchs surrealistic excesses through the more ordered mind of the TV veteran Mark Frost. After all the speculation and worry about what Showtimes new version of the series would be, this weeks double-length opening salvo ended up balancing the disturbingly strange with the merely quirky and the somewhat normal, resulting  yet again  in something as surprisingly accessible as it is singularly bizarre. Two hours in, the third season is already perplexing, unsettling and potentially addicting.

title: A New Dirty Dancing, and Babys Love Story Is Just the Start
description: When Dirty Dancing, a coming-of-age film set in 1963 that depicts a familys summer vacation spent at a Catskills resort, came out in 1987, it was an instant and unexpected sensation. Reportedly costing just $6 million, the movie earned $214 million at the box office and won the best original song Academy Award for (Ive Had) The Time of My Life.

title: The Patient Resilience of Irans Reformers
description: While President Trump basked in the flattery of Saudi Arabias absolute monarchy on Friday, about 75 percent of Iranian voters turned out to repudiate an authoritarian populist and re-elect their moderate president, Hassan Rouhani. Mr. Rouhani ran against extremism and on the promise of human rights, civil liberties, rational economic management and engagement with the world  a platform that won him 57 percent of the vote to his opponents 38.5 percent.

title: Venice Biennale: Whose Reflection Do You See?
description: VENICE  Timing isnt everything, but its a lot. If the bland, soft-power 2017 Venice Biennale, called Viva Arte Viva, had arrived two, or four, or six years ago, it might have passed muster, even made sense. But coming post-Brexit and post-Trump, it feels almost perversely out of sync with the political moment, and nowhere near strong enough to define a moment of its own.

title: Ballet After Balanchine: 3 Choreographers Lead the Way
description: How do you get over George Balanchine? Supreme classicist, supreme modernist and still underrated as a superlative Romantic and dramatist, he remains ballets dominant figure.

title: In Grief Cottage, a Ghost and Other Things That Haunt Us
description: GRIEF COTTAGEBy Gail Godwin324 pages. Bloomsbury. $27.

title: A Tiny Park Fights for Sunlight Among New York City Skyscrapers
description: New Yorkers have to elbow their way onto packed subways below ground. They have to eke out room on teeming sidewalks and streets just to get anywhere.

title: Trump, Flynn, Twin Peaks: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: N.E.H. Chairman to Step Down, Citing Personal Reasons
description: William D. Adams, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, will be stepping down effective Tuesday, the endowment announced, ending a three-year tenure.

title: G.I. Joe, It Turns Out, Had More Than One Father
description: G.I. Joe almost certainly had two fathers.

title: Office of Government Ethics Declines Mulvaneys Request to Suspend Ethics Inquiries
description: Walter M. Shaub, Jr., the director of the Office of Government Ethics, sent a letter on Monday to Mick Mulvaney, director of the Office of Management and Budget, declining a request to suspend its ethics inquiry into individual appointees and practices of agency ethics.

title: Ariana Grande Manchester Concert Ends in Explosion, Panic and Death
description: MANCHESTER, England  An explosion that appeared to be a suicide bombing killed at least 22 people on Monday night and wounded 59 others at an Ariana Grande concert filled with adoring adolescent fans, in what the police were treating as a terrorist attack.

title: Skipping French Open Is a Strategy That Fits Roger Federer
description: ROME  When John Isner received an invitation to play a charity exhibition match in Seattle in late April with Roger Federer, his initial reaction was to double-check the date.

title: Hey Parents, Surprise, Fruit Juice Is Not Fruit
description: Many American children consume more than half of their fruit as juice, and the American Academy of Pediatrics has issued new guidelines clarifying its stance on that substitution: For most kids, its a bad thing.

title: No Fairy Godmother for the Subway: When $100 Billion Isnt Enough
description: ALBANY  Nearly four decades ago, New York Citys subway system hit rock bottom: track fires, graffiti-covered cars and crime came to symbolize that era.

title: At Cannes, the Glam and the Grim Mix Uneasily
description: CANNES, France  The Cannes Film Festival has always been a jarring clash of the glam and the grim, between often dark films and the stars who pose on the red carpet to promote them. This year, news and business developments were as much on the minds of festivalgoers as the movies and the paparazzi. Here are scenes from the first days of the festival:

title: Unusual Place for a Presidents Family on a Foreign Trip: Center Stage
description: JERUSALEM  At an Israeli childrens hospital, Melania Trump handed out blue canvas backpacks filled with Dr. Seuss books and emblazoned with a picture of the White House. At a forum in Saudi Arabia on combating extremism, Ivanka Trump stood in for her father when he got tired. And in Israel, Jared Kushner stuck by his father-in-laws side as President Trump pushed for peace in the Middle East.

title: Battle of Diller Island Goes Another Round, With a Pier 55 Appeal
description: Pier 55, the long-planned $200 million performing arts center on a new pier in the Hudson River, is not dead yet.

title: The Lollipop Guild Rides Again
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Warp-Speed Presidency
description: Gail Collins: Bret, its been a while since I had a chance to converse with a fellow Times columnist. Welcome! And in honor of your arrival, you get to choose our first subject.

title: Zack Snyder to Step Away From Justice League After Daughters Suicide
description: LOS ANGELES  Zack Snyder, the director behind the coming Warner Bros. movie Justice League, said on Monday that he would step away from the mega-budget superhero project to cope with the recent suicide of his daughter.

title: U.N. Panel Releases Draft of Treaty to Ban Nuclear Arms
description: A United Nations disarmament panel presented the first draft on Monday of a proposed global treaty to ban nuclear weapons, which advocates called an important step that could hasten completion of a final text by early July.

title: Quotation of the Day: Billionaire in Montana, Using Trumps Playbook
description: Montana has only one representative, so its important that we get it right.

title: The Latest: Britain Raises Threat Level to Critical After Manchester Attack
description: Prime Minister Theresa May announced on Tuesday night that Britains threat level had been raised to critical, its highest level, suggesting that another terrorist attack may be imminent.

title: Trumps Budget Cuts Deeply Into Medicaid and Anti-Poverty Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump plans to unveil on Tuesday a $4.1 trillion budget for 2018 that would cut deeply into programs for the poor, from health care and food stamps to student loans and disability payments, laying out an austere vision for reordering the nations priorities.

title: Which Off Broadway Shows Did Obie Awards Like Best? Oslo and Underground Railroad Game Share Top Honors
description: An elegant big-cast production at Lincoln Center and an irreverent two-actor work at Ars Nova split a prize for best new American theater work at the annual Obie Awards on Monday night.

title: Dina Merrill, Actress and Philanthropist, Dies at 93
description: Dina Merrill, the actress and heiress to two fortunes who wintered at her familys Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., as a child before becoming a leading lady in movies, most often in upper-class roles, died on Monday at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 93.

title: Trumps First Budget Works Only if Wishes Come True
description: WASHINGTON  In its inaugural budget, the Trump administration projected that booming economic growth would allow the president to keep a wide range of expensive campaign promises while eliminating federal deficits in 10 years.

title: Sessions Narrows Trumps Order Against Sanctuary Cities
description: Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Monday clarified President Trumps executive order on so-called sanctuary cities, narrowly defining such jurisdictions  and the money they could expect to receive from the federal government  in a way that appeared to fall far short of Mr. Trumps previous threats to starve all federal funding from localities that limit their cooperation with federal immigration enforcement.

title: Trump Budget Cuts Programs for Poor While Sparing Many Older People
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps spending blueprint seeks to balance the federal budget through unprecedented cuts to programs for poor and working-class families, effectively pitting them against older Americans who would largely escape the budget ax.

title: Panic After Terrorist Bombing at Ariana Grande Concert
description: ISIS has claimed responsibility for the deadly explosion at an arena in Manchester, England, where the American pop singer Ariana Grande had been performing on Monday night.

title: Manchester Bombing: What We Know and Dont Know
description: Visit this page for full coverage of the episode.

title: Robert H. Boyle, a Watchdog of the Hudson River, Dies at 88
description: Robert H. Boyle, a Brooklyn-born sportswriter and angler who became the unofficial guardian of the Hudson River as a crusading conservationist and a founder of a widely replicated watchdog group called Riverkeeper, died on Friday in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Figure Skating Event
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  One of the things I like about Zhouqin Burnikels puzzles is that, more often than not, she will find some oddity of the English language that typically goes unnoticed and point it out to us.

title: More Evidence Points to North Korea in Ransomware Attack
description: SAN FRANCISCO  More evidence emerged Monday that North Korean hackers were behind the global ransomware attack that still holds hundreds of thousands of computers hostage.

title: The Key Spending Cuts and Increases in Trumps Budget
description: The White House released more details of its federal budget proposal on Monday. It includes substantial cuts to Medicaid and other aid to the poor. Because it comes packaged with tax cuts, it assumes the economy will grow faster as a result and ultimately balance the budget by 2027. It is, however, unlikely to pass Congress as is.

title: A Yankees Win Follows a Duel, and a Review
description: The Yankees beat the Kansas City Royals, 4-2, on Monday at Yankee Stadium in a game that featured three Yankee home runs, one very good performance by a starting pitcher, and the unveiling of a new section of seats in right field designed to look like a courtroom in honor of a rookie slugger.

title: Better Call Saul Season 3, Episode 7 Recap: Jimmy Goes Backward
description: Im starting to think that Better Call Saul is an extended and highly persuasive argument against a career in the law. Everything about the profession as its portrayed here is either dull, odious or cutthroat. The point of Kims outburst with Page in this episode is that Kim feels guilty about roughing up Chuck at that disbarment hearing. But did you recall what was said before and after this flare of temper?

title: Corrections: May 23, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Losing Their Clothes, Finding Themselves
description: Stephanie Thomas stared down the video camera, steeled to shed her clothes and share her deepest insecurities with a roomful of strangers.

title: Smugglers Offer Luxury Passage for Migrants, if They Can Pay
description: AVOLA, Sicily  It was a far cry from the rotting fishing boats and overstuffed dinghies that carry so many thousands of migrants precariously to Italian shores.

title: Manchester, Donald Trump, Uber: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Navy SEAL Team Kills 7 Militants in Yemen During Raid, U.S. Says
description: Members of the Navys elite SEAL Team 6 killed seven militants in central Yemen during an early Tuesday raid on a compound associated with Al Qaeda, American military officials said.

title: Warriors Sweep Spurs to Reach Third Finals in Three Years
description: SAN ANTONIO  The Golden State Warriors rolled past the San Antonio Spurs, 129-115, on Monday night to complete a dominant four-game sweep in the N.B.A.s Western Conference finals.

title: Manchester on Alert: Pictures From the Concert Bombing and the Aftermath
description: As Britain continued to grieve on Friday after an attack earlier this week at an Ariana Grande show in Manchester, England, that killed 22 people, investigators pressed ahead with efforts to unravel the network that is believed to assisted the bomber, Salman Abedi.

title: Scott Dixon, Indy Pole Winner, Robbed on Fast-Food Run
description: After winning the Indianapolis 500 pole, collecting a $100,000 check and doing the usual interview circuit, Scott Dixon tried to relax. Instead, he got the scare of his life.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday: Casual and Frontline: Bannons War
description: Save some affection for Casual, the Golden Globe-nominated Hulu tale about a family with issues  lots of them. Or feed your political appetite with The Ides of March and Frontline: Bannons War.

title: Word + Quiz: duplicity
Need Mood Lighting to Go With Your Music? Ask Alexa. No App Required.
description: SEATTLE  Today, most people know Amazons Echo speaker as an easy way to play music using voice commands, but the device and others like it are catching on as ways to control light switches, thermostats and other smart home appliances.

title: Park Geun-hye, Ousted Leader of South Korea, Denies All Charges in Court
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Park Geun-hye, South Koreas recently impeached and ousted president, made her first appearance in court on Tuesday, denying all criminal charges against her, as one of the biggest trials in the countrys history began.

title: With the 2018 Olympics in South Korea, Will the North Be Participant or Provocateur?
description: As preparations accelerate for the 2018 Winter Olympics in South Korea, sporting relations on the divided Korean Peninsula in recent years have seldom appeared more amicable, despite the building nuclear tensions and escalating talk of war.

title: Writers From the Right and Left React to Trumps Riyadh Speech, and More
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: Barcelona Attack Adds to the Toll of Terrorism in Western Europe
description: Islamic extremists have carried out over a dozen deadly terror attacks in Western Europe since 2015.

title: Rethinking How Science Is Seen
description: Since their earliest days, photography and science have been intertwined, going from single images of fleeting phenomena to using cameras that shoot a trillion frames per second.

title: The U.N.s Complicity in a Congo Murder
description: The Democratic Republic of Congo, formerly Zaire, has endured a remarkably cruel history, with successive presidents, rebels and foreign powers endlessly pillaging its rich resources and leaving behind a trail of massacres, rapes and devastation. The military has contributed its share of atrocities, and the current president, Joseph Kabila, has compounded the chaos by refusing to step down or hold elections since his term ended last December.

title: Health Policy Is Vital to Tax Reform Policy
description: Today the House Ways and Means Committee is scheduled to hold a hearing on improving the competitiveness of American businesses. It should consider health policy as well as tax policy in its deliberations.

title: President Trumps Mideast Contradictions
description: Given President Trumps appetite for spectacle, Saudi Arabia could not have been a more fitting opening for his first overseas trip. The palaces, the fancy robes of King Salman and his court, the sword dance, even the creepy glowing orb used to inaugurate Saudi Arabias new counterterrorism center, seemed just the right props for a former television celebrity. His hosts went out of their way to indulge his weakness for flattery and deal-making. Mr. Trump tried hard to make amends to the Muslim world he had spent many months insulting.

title: When the War Came Home
description: If you visit the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, go to Panel 20, Line 3. It is near the top, so you might have to crane your neck. There you will find the name Donald M. Peterson. Pete, as he was known to his buddies, was the lone American to die in a small-scale battle that took place in the Mekong Delta on May 15, 1967  a battle recounted in a column in this series last week.

title: A Budget That Promises Little but Pain
description: If President Trumps 2018 budget, to be unveiled on Tuesday, was worthy of praise, you can bet Mr. Trump would be in Washington to bask in it. But his overseas trip keeps him at a distance physically, if not politically.

title: Its Time to Worry about Health Care in the Senate
description: While the rest of the country has been transfixed by Trumpian chaos, members of the Senate have spent the last two weeks talking about taking health insurance from millions of Americans.

title: My Family Didnt Accept Me. Ole Miss Did.
description: OXFORD, MISS.  It may sound surprising, but many colleges in the Deep South are welcoming environments for gay students. Until my freshman year at the University of Mississippi, I never felt free to be myself.

title: The Alienated Mind
description: The campaign of 2016 was an education in the deep problems facing the country. Angry voters made a few things abundantly clear: that modern democratic capitalism is not working for them; that basic institutions like the family and communities are falling apart; that we have a college educated elite that has found ingenious ways to make everybody else feel invisible, that has managed to transfer wealth upward to itself, that crashes the hammer of political correctness down on anybody who does not have faculty lounge views.

title: Googles AlphaGo Defeats Chinese Go Master in Win for A.I.
description: HONG KONG  It isnt looking good for humanity.

title: Rethinking How Science Is Seen
description: Photographs in and about science have long influenced the trajectory of discovery and of public opinion and policy, too. In 1948, Fred Hoyle, a British astronomer, made an astonishing prediction: Once a photograph of the Earth, taken from the outside, is available . . . a new idea as powerful as any in history will be let loose. Two decades later, NASA photographs such as The Blue Marble (1972)  one of the most widely reproduced images ever  did just that, startling us with dramatically new perspectives on our place in the broader scheme of things.

title: Patient Voices: Tourette's Syndrome
description: Sudden jerking movements, uncontrollable tics and strange vocalizations. Six men and women talk about living with Tourettes syndrome.

title: Terror Alert in Britain Is Raised to Maximum as ISIS Claims Manchester Attack
description: MANCHESTER, England  Britains prime minister put the nation on its highest level of alert on Tuesday and deployed the military to work with the police over fears that another terrorist attack was imminent.

title: Questions for: Looming Floods, Threatened Cities
description: Article: Looming Floods, Threatened Cities

title: The Car Spins. Tires Squeal. She Relaxes.
description: Stacey Lee May is one of South Africas first female professional car spinners. Get behind the wheel with her in this 360 video.

title: Manchester Attack Changes the Conversation for Trumps Trip
description: JERUSALEM  President Trump headed on Tuesday to Europe, where a devastating attack at a pop music concert in Manchester, England, grimly underscored his demand that Arab and Muslim countries drive extremists out of this earth and offered the first real test of how the president would respond to a searing terror strike.

title: Can Anyone Be Truly Independent In Todays Polarized Politics?
description: Late in the 19th century, America was besieged by grave problems: rising economic inequality, violent labor struggles, deep conflicts over immigration and race. But the nations leaders seemed incapable of addressing any of these things; they frittered away their hours in disputes over tariffs and trade, and when election time came, they lined up in their respective parties, each one hoping for the chance to distribute the federal spoils to itself. Presidential elections were achingly close: In 1888, Grover Cleveland won the popular vote but lost to Benjamin Harrison in the Electoral College, fueling a sense that the political process no longer worked properly.

title: Where Did the Great Hollywood Baseball Movie Go?
description: This spring, trying to bring some routine to my life as a new father, I made a pledge to watch a lot more baseball. It started out well enough: The Mets, my adopted team, ran out to a reasonably strong start before the injuries and losses started piling up in late April. But my attention also wandered, much more so than it does when I watch basketball or football. My pseudoscientific interest in the sport has long since passed  there was a time when I would dive into any statistical study with the same delight as a biology student first dissecting a frog and seeing how all the organs connect beneath the surface. Now that baseball has become more of a therapeutic diversion, I find myself wishing I knew how to put the frog back together.

title: Dear Match Book: What Should I Read on My Summer Vacation?
description: Dear Match Book,

title: Is the Internet Broken?
description: What is the purpose of the internet? Should it be a place where everyone can speak freely and exchange information and ideas? Or, does that kind of open forum end up privileging the loudest and most extreme voices? Does it naturally lead to trolling, fake news and click bait?

title: New Sentences: From Augustown, by Kei Miller
description: In Jamaica, in 1920, something unbelievable is happening: A preacher has started to fly. The news has spread across the island, where it is accepted or disputed, cheered or mocked, depending on the audience receiving it. Believers are full of hope; elites are threatened; revolution is in the air.

title: Former C.I.A. Chief Tells of Concern Over Possible Russia Ties to Trump Campaign
description: John O. Brennan, the former director of the C.I.A., said publicly for the first time Tuesday that he was concerned about possible ties between Russia and the Trump campaign.

title: Jared Kushners Other Real Estate Empire in Baltimore
description: This article is a collaboration between The Times and ProPublica, the independent nonprofit investigative-journalism organization.

title: Critical Thinkers: The Ties That Bind Orwell and Churchill
description: CHURCHILL AND ORWELL The Fight for Freedom By Thomas E. Ricks Illustrated. 339 pp. Penguin Press. $28.

title: Is It Possible to Resist Deportation in Trumps America?
description: On Monday, Feb. 6, two days before Guadalupe Garca Aguilar made headlines as the first person deported under President Donald Trumps new executive orders on immigration, she and her family drove to the modest stucco offices of Puente, an organization that represents undocumented immigrants. It was a postcard day: warm and dry, hovering around 70 degrees, the kind of winter afternoon that had long ago turned Phoenix into a magnet for American retirees and the younger, mostly Latin American immigrants who mulch their gardens and build their homes.

title: Aprils Book Club Pick: The Death and Life of the Great Lakes, by Dan Egan
description: THE DEATH AND LIFE OF THE GREAT LAKES By Dan Egan Illustrated. 364 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $27.95.

title: Even Harley-Davidson Cant Resist the Tug of Overseas Factories
description: HONG KONG  President Trump has held up Harley-Davidson as a pillar of American manufacturing.

title: Malaysian Money. Opulent Ideas. But Now, for Park Lane, a Forced Sale.
description: The celebratory dinner was held at one of the citys chicest restaurants, whose building offers a picture-perfect view down Central Park South to the Park Lane Hotel, a 47-story tower that looms over its more famous neighbor, the Plaza.

title: Fighting Trump on Climate, California Becomes a Global Force
description: LOS ANGELES  The environmental ministers of Canada and Mexico went to San Francisco last month to sign a global pact  drafted largely by California  to lower planet-warming greenhouse pollution. Gov. Jerry Brown flies to China next month to meet with climate leaders there on a campaign to curb global warming. And a battery of state lawyers is preparing to battle any attempt by Washington to weaken Californias automobile pollution emission standards.

title: Apple Settles Legal Dispute With Nokia
description: Apple and Nokia settled a legal dispute on Tuesday over the right of the iPhone maker to use patents and other intellectual property owned by the Finnish telecommunications company.

title: James Corden Pays Tribute to Manchester in Heartfelt Monologue
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.
